The steer was on the point of upbraiding his maternal relative for deserting him, when a cream-colored heifer calf came up and nourished itself at the cow's udder. That was too much for him. Though he fought valiantly the battle is ever with the strong, and inch by inch he was forced backward.. Two-year-old heifer was caught by his rival and cut a cruel gash in his shoulder. He renounced kith and kin, the speckled heifer and the Nueces valley forever. He firmly resolved to start at once for the Frio country. He was a proud two-year old and had always held his head high. Could his spirit suffer the humiliation of meeting his old companions after such defeat?. The line-back steer had never witnessed such a procession of his kind before. He distinctly remembered the physical pain he had suffered once in a branding-pen, but that was nothing compared to this. He hardly knew which way to turn. Finally he concluded to lie down on a knoll and rest until nightfall, when he would start on his journey to the Frio. He was a cautious fellow; he knew he must have water on the way, and the rains had not yet fallen. The line- back steer saw something new, for coming over the brow of the hill was a great column of cattle.. The line-back steer classed them as strangers, probably bound for the Frio. When he attempted to join in, a dark-skinned man on a horse chased him away. Once again he tried to enter the herd, but an outrider cut him off. He would leave the Nueces valley with those cattle--or alone, it mattered not. He threw the very intensity of his existence into his resolution of the morning. He followed at a respectful distance.. The man was well mounted, and running his horse up to him he took up his tail, wrapped the brush around the pommel of his saddle, and by a dexterous turn of his horse threw him until he spun like a top. The ground was sandy, and while the throwing frightened him, never for an instant did it shake his determination. He complimented himself on his craftiness, but never dreamed that this was a trail herd, bound for some other. "He swam rivers and grazed in contentment across flowery prairies, mesas and broken country. Yet it mattered nothing to him where he was going, for his every need was satisfied. Lily was fond of throwing stones at the turtles on the rocks. She was also fond of her red sun-umbrella. She carried it with her when she went out in a gale of wind. The wind nearly took the umbrella out of her hand. She always wanted to go up in a balloon. She loved to throw stones at them. She also loved to play with them.. Lily fell down, down, till she went crash into a tree which grew in such a curious place that she forgot her fright. The tree looked as if made of glass or colored sugar; for she could see through the red cherries, the green leaves, and the brown branches. An agreeable smell met her nose; and she said at once, as any child would, "I smell candy!". Lily discovered that the snow under her feet was white sugar. The rocks were lumps of chocolate, the flowers of all colors and tastes. Little white houses soon appeared; and here lived the dainty candy-people. Bits of babies rocked in open-work cradles, and sugar boys and girls played with sugar toys in the most natural way.. Lily listened, and in a moment she understood what the song said. Carriages rolled along the jujube streets, drawn by the red and yellow barley horses we all love so well. cows fed in the green fields, and sugar birds sang in the trees. Lily ran up the chocolate steps into the pretty rooms, where all the. Lily was quite happy, going about tasting so many different kinds of sweeties. The babies were made of plain sugar, but the grown people had different flavors. The young ladies were flavored with violet, rose, and orange. The gentlemen were apt to have cordials of some sort inside of them, as she found when she ate one now and then slyly, and got her tongue bitten by the hot, strong taste as a punishment.. Lily discovered that it never rained, but snowed white sugar. Ginger was called to her more than once when so much candy made her teeth ache. They played football with big bull's-eyes, sailed in sugar boats on lakes of syrup, fished in rivers of molasses, and rode the barley horses all over the country.. The people all lived on sugar, and never quarrelled. If any got broken, they just stuck the parts together and were all right again. The way they grew old was to get thinner and thinner till there was danger of their vanishing. The feasts were delicious; and everybody went in their best clothes, and danced at the ball till they got so warm half-a-dozen would stick together and have to be taken to the ice-cream room to cool off.. Lily was a sweet child, and loved to eat all the sweet stuff in the country. She would eat the sweet babies and break up the old people. The Minister was a very fat man, predisposed to apoplexy, and as it was necessary therefore to spare him every dangerous emotion, the took the minutest precautions in warning him that a serious attempt upon his life had been planned. The attempt was to be made the next day, at the moment when His Excellency was to leave the house to go to make his report. A few terrorists, armed with revolvers and bombs, were to meet near. "How do they know that I am to go to present my report at one o'clock in the afternoon, when I learned it myself only two days ago?" asked the Minister. The commander of the body-guard made a vague gesture signifying ignorance. The Minister felt a sensation of agreeable excitement. It seemed to him that he had just received, or was about to receive, a great and unexpected reward. But the friends went away, and the lights were put out. The lights gleamed in this new residence.. Dignitary was afflicted with a kidney trouble. Every violent emotion caused his face, feet, and hands to swell. He felt his face puff up and become, as it were, something foreign to his body. His thought recurred obstinately to the cruel fate that his enemies were preparing for him. He evoked one after the other all the horrible attempts of recent date. It seemed to him that his diseased body was another man's body suffering from the fiery shock of the explosion. And, at these recollections, it seemed to he that his disease was another person's disease. He suffered the anguish of the sick as he felt his faces puff up.. "Brave fellows! Brave fellows!" he exclaimed in a loud and clear voice. But in vain did he stir about, lavish his praise, and smile at the discomfiture of the terrorists. It seemed to him that the death evoked for him by the anarchists, and which existed in their thought, was already there and would remain there, refusing to go away until the assassins should be seized, deprived of their bombs, and lodged safely in prison. "Brave fellows" were the words of a man who had been shot in the head by an anarchist.. "At one o'clock in the afternoon, Your Excellency!" This phrase came back to him continually, uttered in all tones, now joyously and ironically, now irritably, now obstinately and stupidly. There it stood, in the corner yonder, declining to leave, and unable to leave. Before it and after it no other hour existed; it alone; presumptuous and obsessing, was entitled to a special life. It had stepped out of the clock-dial, and was beginning to live a distinct life, stretching itself.. "Ah!" suddenly exclaimed the Minister aloud; slowly he removed his hands from his face. Gazing far before him into the darkness with a fixed and attentive look, he stretched out his hand to turn on the light. Then he arose, and in his bare feet walked around the strange chamber so unfamiliar to him; finding another light, he turned that on also. . . . And it is he, this good and thoughtful Swiss, with the blue eyes, and the open countenance, and. the numerous military decorations—he it is who opens the terrible door with his own hands.. The Minister resembled, those old people who are tormented by asthma and insomnia. Without dressing he threw, himself into an arm-chair, his eyes wandered to the ceiling. The room became bright and agreeable; there was only the disordered bed and the fallen coverlet to indicate a terror that had not yet completely disappeared. "Evidently," he thought with lucidity, "I am afraid now because I have been warned and because I know. But, if I had been left in ignorance, I should have taken my coffee quietly. And then, evidently, this death.". "I have a kidney trouble; some day I must die of it, and yet I am not afraid, because I don't know when," he says. "To die is not so terrible; the terrible thing is to know that one is going to die," he adds. "It would be quite impossible for a man to live if he knew the hour and day of his death with absolute certainty," he writes. "And yet these idiots warn me: 'At one o'clock in the afternoon, Your Excellency!'". No man can know when he will die. Once, in his youth, it had happened to him to get beyond his depth; he had decided to put an end to his existence. He had loaded his revolver, written some letters, and even fixed the hour of his suicide. Then, at the last moment, he had reconsidered. He admitted that they would kill him some day or other, but it would not be the next day . . . it wouldn't be thenext day.. The Minister understood that he would know neither sleep, nor rest, nor joy, until this black and accursed hour, thus detached from the course of time, had passed. He feared the unexpected, the inevitable: an attack of apoplexy, a laceration of the heart, the rupture of a little artery suddenly made powerless to resist the flow of blood and splitting like a glove on swollen hands. The fear of death permeated his entire body, filtered into his bones, exuded from every pore of his body. He dared not look at his swollen fingers, full of some fatal fluid.. People came running. On every hand appeared these shadows: they arose in the corners and stretched out upon the ceiling, fastening upon all projections and running along the walls. Ivan Yanson had been hired as a farm-hand by a well-to-do farmer. He was a native of Wesenberg, in Esthonia. Yanson remained silent for almost two years. He said hardly a word to either man or beast. He led the horse to water and harnessed it without speaking to it, walking about it lazily, with short hesitating steps. He had very little knowledge of Russian. As there were none of his countrymen living in the neighborhood, and as his employer was a Russian. Yanson beat the horse cruelly with his enormous whip. Drink transformed his cold and wicked obstinacy into fury. The hissing of the lash and the regular and painful sound of his wooden shoes on the floor of the shed could be heard even at the farmhouse. To punish him for torturing the horse the farmer at first beat Yanson, but, not succeeding in correcting him, he gave it up. He came back to the farm on the gallop, a distance of seven mlles.. Yanson did not see the passers-by, he did not insult them, uphill and down he maintained his furious gait. Sometimes silent, with set teeth, impelled by a whirlwind of indescribable fury, suffering, and enthusiasm, he was like a blind man in his mad career. One day he received a letter written in Esthonian; but, as he didnot know how to read or write, he threw it into the muck-heap with savage indifference.. One night, in the village, the little church-bell began to ring in a feeble and lamentable way; flames appeared. Malefactors from nobody knew where were pillaging the neighboring farm. They killed the owner and his wife, and set fire to the house. This caused a feeling of anxiety on the farm where Yanson lived. He alone knew what the fields and telegraph-poles were saying. He listened also to the conversation of men, the stories of murder, pillage,. Ivan Yanson, who was afraid of a gun, committed robbery and murder, and made an attempt at rape. He stabbed his master several times in the back. He found the money; then, as if he had just seen the master's wife for the first time, he threw himself upon her to rape her, without the slightest premeditation. But he happened to drop his knife; and, as the woman was the stronger, she not only resisted Yanson but half strangled him. Yanson was later sentenced to life in prison, but was released on parole.. Yanson was tried and sentenced to death. He was found an hour later squatting in the corner of the shed, and scratching matches which continually went out. He had been trying to set fire to the farm. A few days later the farmer died. Yanson fled. He turned scarlet, and began to untie and tie his cravat, as if it were choking him. When the sentence of death by hanging was pronounced, Yanson suddenly showed emotion. He began to undo and tie the cravats. He then began to walk away.. Yanson waved his arms without knowing why, and declared to the presiding judge, who had read the sentence: "She has said that I must be hanged" Yanson pointed at the judge with his finger, and, looking at him furt. "I must not be hanged!" repeated Yanson, obstinately. "Well, you are a famous imbecile," said the guard. "Take away the accused," replied the guard, in violation of orders. "I will not be taken away!" said Yanson. "You will not take me away." "I am not going to be taken to jail," said a guard, "and you are not taking me to jail." "You are not a man. "It is not a question of hanging a dog, which one takes behind a shed and dispatches with a single blow! Is that what you would like, imbecile?" said the guard. "Why, no, I would not like it!" said Yanson suddenly with a joyous grimace. "I would rather be hanged!" said the prisoner.. Yanson was about to be hanged when he began to laugh. Babouscka sat in her snug little house by her warm fire. It was the night the dear Christ-Child came to Bethlehem. The wind was drifting the snow outside and howling down the chimney. Three old men stood outside in the snow with their beards as white as the snow.. Babouscka went inside and shut the door, and the old men journeyed on to Bethlehem without her. The storekeeper had the reputation of being a conscientious, high-minded man. He knew that he was thus estimated, and self-complacently appropriated the good opinion as clearly his due. The love of gain was strong in his mind, and ever ready to accede to new plans for adding dollar to dollar. But a disturbing perception of something wrong restrained him.. "Twenty yards at fifty-five cents! Just eleven dollars." The customer opened her purse as she spoke, and counted out the sum in glittering gold dollars. "Send the bundle to No. 300 Argyle Street," said the lady, with a bland smile, as she turned from the counter, and the half-bewildered store. A single dollar on the conscience may press so heavily as to bear down a man's spirits, and rob him of all the delights of life. Vain was it that Mr. Levering sought self-justification. He found it impossible to escape the smarting conviction that he had unjustly exacted a dollar from one of his customers. Many times through the day he found himself in a musing, abstracted state.. The dollar was on his conscience, and he sought in vain to remove it by efforts of this kind. "Very foolish to worry myself about a trifle like this," he thought. "The goods were cheap enough at fifty-five, and she is quite as well contented with her bargain as if she had paid only fifty.". "Are you sick, papa?" asks a bright little fellow, clambering upon his knee. "I'm perfectly well," he replies, rousing himself, and forcing a smile. "Because you don't play horses with. "Does your head ache, pa?" inquired the child who had previously suggested sickness, as he saw his father leave the floor, and seat himself, with some gravity of manner, on a chair. "Not this evening, dear," answered Mr. Levering. "Why don't you play longer, then?". "Emma Wilson saw him do it, and they found the dollar in his pocket. Oh! he looked so pale, and it made me almost sick to hear him cry as if his heart would break" "Will he ever forget his crime and disgrace? Will the pressure of that dollar on his conscience ever be removed?" "He may never do so wicked an act again; but the memory of this wrong deed cannot be wholly effaced from. Mr. Levering saw his customer of the day previous enter, and move along towards the place where he stood behind his counter. An accusing conscience was quick to conclude as to the object of her visit. But he soon saw that no suspicion of wrong dealing was in the lady's mind. Still there was a pressure on his feelings, which thought could trace to that unlucky dollar.. The storekeeper was counting out the change due his customer. He purposely gave her one dollar more than was justly hers in that transaction. The lady glanced her eyes over the money, and seemed slightly bewildered. Then, much to the storekeeper's relief, opened her purse and dropped it therein. "All right again!" was the mental ejaculation of Mr. Levering, as he saw the purse disappear.. "I'll throw it into the street," said he to himself, impatiently. "Or give it to the first beggar that comes along" But conscience whispered that the dollar wasn't his, either to give away or to throw away.. "This is all squeamishness," said Mr. Levering trying to argue against his convictions. His convictions remained as clear and rebuking as ever. Such prodigality, or impulsive benevolence, would be at the expense of another, and this could not mend the matter.. Mr. Levering dropped the dollar into the contribution box at the close of the morning service. He could not send it back to the lady and tell her the whole truth. Such an exposure of himself would not only be humiliating, but hurtful to his character. It would be seeking to do right, in the infliction of a wrong to himself. At last, Mr Levering decided to give the money to the treasury.. The writer, Mr. Levering, who had ascertained the lady's name and residence, inclosed her a dollar, anonymously, stating that it was her due. He felt not only disgraced in his own eyes, but humbled in the presence of his wife and children. Not for worlds would he have suffered them to look into his heart. The deed was entered in the book of his life, and nothing could efface the record.. "Take warning by Mr. Levering, and beware how, in a moment of weak yielding, you get a dollar on your conscience" "One of two evils must follow. It will give you pain

"Arty, darling!" called Mrs. Mayflower, from the window, one bright June morning. "Run after him, Mr Mayflower!" But baby was in eager pursuit of something, and the call, if heard, was unheeded. His eyes were opening world-ward, and every new phenomenon--commonplace and unheeding by us--that addressed itself to his senses, became a wonder and a delight. Some new object was drawing him away from the loving heart and protecting arm of his mother. "Arty! Arty!" she said. "What is the child after? Just look at him,Mr. Mayflorence!". "What is it, darling? What is Arty running after?" I said, as I laid my hand on his arm, and checked his eager speed. He struggled a moment, and then stood still, stooping forward for something on the ground. There was a disappointed and puzzled look in his face as he lifted his eyes to mine. He failed to secure the object of his pursuit. "It's only your shadow! Foolish child!" I exclaimed, catching him up in my arms. And I ran back to Mrs. Mayflower, with a touch of anxiety in her voice. "He might fall and hurt himself.". "So life begins--and so it ends! Poor Arty!" I said to myself. "Always in pursuit of shadows! We lose to-day's substantial good for shadowy phantoms that keep our eyes ever in advance, and our feet ever hurrying forward!" "O, deluded heart!--ever bartering away substance for shadow!" I thought. "I grow philosophic sometimes" I said. "How little the wiser are we for moralizing!" I added. "We look into the mirror of truth, and see ourselves--then turn away, and forget what manner of men we are". The author's daily routine was disturbed by impatient aspirations. He spent the larger part of this day in the perpetration of a plan for increasing his gains beyond, anything heretofore achieved. The regular, orderly progression of a fair and well-established business was too slow for his outreaching desires. Better for us if it were not so; if we remembered the image that held our vision, he says. He writes: "Better for us to remember the image of our vision." The author is a self-taught writer and author of several books. He is also a successful businessman and author-turned-businessman. He lives in New York City with his wife and two children. He has a son, a daughter, a son-in-law, and a grandson.. "Mr. B----, of Alton?" said I, affecting an effort of memory. "Does he look like a fair man?" "Yes, sir; but it may be prudent to send and get a report." "I'll see to that, Edward," said I. "Sell him what he wants. If everything is not on the square, I'll give you the word in time" "It's all right, I've no doubt," said my clerk. "Let him have what he want, Edward". "I forgot all about Mr. B----, and the trifling bill of a thousand dollars that he proposed buying. How clear the way looked ahead! As thought created the means of successful adventure, and I saw myself moving forward and grasping results, the whole circle of life took a quicker motion" "I grew impatient for the initiatory steps that were to come, and felt as if the to-morrow, in which they must be taken, would never appear" "A day seemed like a week or a month. A cloud settled down upon it here, and a cloud there, breaking up its unity, and destroying much of its fair proportion" "We needn't hesitate. sell him, we needn’t hesitate." "I am not a man who can be persuaded to do anything he doesn't want to do.". "Have the goods sold to that new customer from Alton been delivered?" I asked, as the real interest of my wasted day loomed up into sudden importance. "Yes, sir," was answered by one of my clerks; "they were sent to Kline & Co.'s immediately" "He's a safe man, I should think," I said. "He was a good man," said the clerk. "I'm sure he was," I replied. "But he's a bad man, too." "He is," replied the clerk, "but he's not a dangerous man." "I am a good person," said I, "and he is a bad person." "And I am a dangerous person, too," said he, ". "They sell him only for cash," said my clerk. "It has a bad look," said I. "How large a bill did he make with us?" "Five or six times beyond the amount of his purchases with them" "He's a new man, who bought a moderate cash bill, but was sending in large quantities of goods to be packed," said the clerk, "and they sell him." "Is that so!" I exclaimed, rising to my feet, all awake now to the real things which I had permitted. "What! I thought he was to buy only to the amount of a thousand dollars?" I returned, in surprise and dismay. "Seventeen hundred dollars," replied the clerk. "It's too late," answered my clerk, "B----called a little after one o'clock, and gave notes for the amount" "I think, Edward," said I, "that you'd better step round to Kline & Co.'s, and ask if they've shipped B----'s goods yet" "If not, we'll request them to delay long enough in the morning to give us time. "You look very sober, Mr. Mayflower," said my good wife, gazing at me with eyes a little shaded by concern, as I sat with Arty's head leaning against my bosom that evening. "As sober as baby looked this morning, after his fruitless shadow chase," I replied. "I have been chasing a shadow all day; a mere phantom scheme of profit," I continued. "And at night-fall I not only lose my shadow, but find my feet far off from the right path, and bemired." "I called Arty a foolish child this morning. I laughed at his mistake," I said.. Mrs. Mayflower sighed gently. "I am afraid we are all, more or less, in pursuit of shadows," she said. "When night falls our phantom good is dispersed, and we sigh for the real good we might have enjoyed" "Happiness is no shadow. It is a real thing," she replied. "We shall never grow happier unless we do," said Mrs. Mayflorence. "Shall we never grow wiser?" I asked. "Yes," she answered. "You will." "We will," I replied. 'We will." 'We shall grow wiser' 'We'll grow happier,' she said, 'unless we do'. "Few, if any, I fear," she answered; "and few, if many, are happy" "Happiness is a state of life," she said. "It does not project itself in advance of us" "It comes only to those who do each day's work peaceful self-forgetfulness," she added. "And a calm trust in the Giver of all good for the blessing that lies stored for each one prepared to receive it in every hour of the coming time" "We cannot catch it by pursuit," she replied. "That is only a cheating counterfeit, in guilt and tinsel, which dazzles our eyes in the ever receding future". "No--no! Not yet, my sweet one!" answered Mrs. Mayflower, hugging him to her heart. "Not yet. We cannot spare you from our world of shadows" "We are always losing the happiness of our to-days; and our to to-morrows never come," said Arty, who lay fast asleep on my bosom

Jonas Bebee has one merit, if he possesses no other, and that is, the merit of being able to make himself completely at home with all his friends. His good opinion of himself leaves no room for his imagination to conceive the idea, that possibly there may be, in his character, certain peculiarities not agreeable to all. It never occurs to him, that he may chance to make a mal apropos visit, nor that the prolongation of a call may be a serious annoyance. He is so entirely satisfied with himself that he is sure every one else must feel his presence as a kind of sunshine. His evening calls upon ladies generally produce a marked effect upon those specially selected for the favor.. The effect is most apparent in the parlor of a house. The servants are annoyed by a man in the room. The ladies are annoyed with him too. The effect is more pronounced in the kitchen. The men are annoyed at the ladies. The women are annoyed. The man is annoyed at them. The result is the effect of the scene in question. The character of the effect will appear in the following little scene, which we briefly sketch. The scene is called "Gentleman in the Parlor. "I hate the very sight of him!" says one of the young ladies. "So, come, let's put on the best face possible" "You can go, Cara, if you choose, but I'm in no hurry," says Mr. Bebee. "No, you must all make your own apologies," says the servant. "I'll be along in the course of half an hour," he adds. "You must all be in good humor," says Cara. "It's no use fretting ourselves over the annoyance, we've got to endure it." "I hate his very sight," says another, "but I'm not in any hurry." "No," says a third, "I'm in good humour.". Jonas Bebee is on familiar terms with all his friends, that he can waive all ceremony. If told that the lady is not at home, a suspicion that it may not be so does not cross his mind. He knows, as any one, that visits of politeness should be brief. But he generally does so, making himself "at home," as he says, wherever he goes. He felt that he was neglecting her. So he started forth to make her a call. It was Saturday, and Mrs. Fairview was at home. She said she would be happy to see him. Mr. Bebee said he would be glad to see her. He said he had not seen her for some weeks.. Mrs. Fairview had been in the kitchen making cake. She came up to the parlor to dust and re-arrange some of the articles there a little more to her liking. She was about to leave the house, when some one rung the bell. Gliding noiselessly to the window, she obtained a view of Mr. Bebee. "O, dear!" she sighed, "am I to have this infliction to-day? But it's no use; I won't see him!" "Hannah!" called the lady, in a whisper, beckoning.. Hannah Fairview's mistress, looking more like a scarecrow than a genteel lady, was still in the parlor. The visiter was disposed to pass her by and make himself a temporary occupant of the same room. "I'll just step in for a little while and enjoy myself," said the gentleman. "It's a bitter cold day--perhaps she will be home sooner." "I don't think she will return before two o'clock," said Hannah, knowing that her mistress was still.. Hannah, the girl's mother, told her that her mistress would not come back until dinner-time. Mrs. Fairview, who had been eagerly listening to what passed between Hannah and the visiter, found that he was about invading her parlor, and seeing no way of escape, retreated into a little room, or office, built off from and communicating only with the parlor. As she entered this room and shut the door, the cold air penetrated her garments and sent a chill through her frame. In despair, Hannah ran back to her place in the kitchen, wondering what her mistress was going to say or do when Mr. Bebee found that she was at home--and, moreover, in such a plight!. The parlor had but a single door, and that one led into the parlor. There was no carpet on the floor of this little box of a place, and it contained neither sofa, chair, nor anything else to sit upon. Escape, therefore, was cut off, entirely; and to remain long where she was could not be done except at the risk of taking a severe cold. The prospect was, that he would thus remain "at home," for at least the next half hour, if not longer. What was she to do? The thermometer was almost down to zero, and she was dressed for a temperature of seventy. "I shall catch my death a cold," she sighed, as the chilly air penetrated her garments.. Mrs. Fairview saw Mr. Bebee in front of the roaring grate, rocking himself in the great arm-chair, and enjoying a new book which he had found upon the table. Five, ten, fifteen, twenty minutes elapsed--but there sat the visiter, deeply absorbed in his book. Mrs. Fairview, who by this time was beginning to suffer, besides excessive fatigue, from a sharp pain through her breast to her left shoulder blade, determined to make her escape at all hazards. Mr. Beebe raised his head at this unexpected invasion of the parlor, but on reflection concluded that the person who so suddenly appeared and disappeared was merely a servant in the family. "Did you ever see such a queer looking figure?" a woman asked her companion. She was riding along in an open carriage, a short distance from the city, accompanied by a relative. She had on a faded calico dress, short in the waist; stout leather shoes; the remains of what had once been a red merino long shawl.. The young girl's countenance was youthful, but plain almost to homeliness. The smallness of her eyes, which were close together and placed at the Mongolian angle, gave to her countenance a singular aspect. The young man gently drew on the rein of his horse so as still further to diminish his speed.. "You look like a gentleman and a lady," said a man whom was riding by, and happened to overhear some of their last remarks. "Your conduct is anything but gentlemanly and lady-like," he said. "I would advise them to keep you in until you had sense and decency enough not to disgrace yourselves". "You will hear from me in good time," said the stranger. "I'll teach him a lesson!" said the elegant young man with contempt. "How he frightened me!" ejaculated the young lady as her rather crestfallen companion laid the whip upon his horse and dashed ahead.. The pair were thrown from a carriage in a secluded place. The young man received only a slight bruise, but the girl was more seriously injured. The pair were riding across the country in order to reach another avenue leading into the city, but missed his way and bewildered in a maze of winding country roads. They had been thoughtless, to say the least of it.. A young man saw a woman hit her head on a stone and was unable to move. He raised his voice and cried "Help!" The door of a cabin flung open and a woman and boy looked eagerly around. The young man recognized instantly in the woman the person they had so wantonly insulted only an hour or. The girl was taken to a house by a kind-hearted woman. She was very ill, and the man carried her to the house. The woman was a woman of the house, and was very kind. The man asked, eagerly, if there was a doctor near.. "He has gone for the doctor; but will be back very soon," said the young woman, in a kind, soothing voice. "If you will come to the door, I will show you the doctor's house," she said. "I think he must be at home, for I saw him go by only a quarter of an hour since. The young girl's face was one of identification; and even amid the terror that oppressed her heart, the unwilling visitor felt a sense of painful mortification. With a frightened cry she fell backs upon the pillow from which she had risen. "O, I am glad!" she repeated. "It might have been so much worse.". The young couple looked at each other with dismay pictured in their countenances. "I wish it were in my power to make you more comfortable," said the kind-hearted girl. "What we have is at your service in welcome, and all that it is in myPower to do shall be done for you cheerfully," replied the young man. The young woman became sick and faint, and remained so until the physician came.. The young man dazed upon her in wonder and shame--wonder at the charm that now appeared in her singularly marked countenance, and shame for the disgraceful and cowardly cruelty with which he had a little while before so wantonly assailed her. After seeing his unhappy relative in as comfortable a condition as possible, the young man, with the doctor's aid. The young girl was not really bad at heart; but false estimates of things, trifling associations, and a thoughtless disregard of others, had made her far less a lady in act than she imagined herself to be in quality. The delicacy of her attentions, and the absence of everything like a desire to refund her of the recent unpleasant incident, marked her as possessing, even if her face and attire were plain, and her position humble.. "O, no, sir!" she said, drawing back, while a glow came into her pale face, and made it almost beautiful; "I have only done a simple duty." "Your reward is great," said the father, touched with the noble answer, "may God bless you, my good girl!" "If you will not receive my money, accept my grateful thanks. The humbled girl grasped her hand tightly, and murmured, "I shall never forget you--never!" "Get his forgiveness, and all will be right," she said. "You have mine, and also the prayer of my heart that you may be good and wise, for only such are happy" The incident of that day were a life-lesson that never passed entirely from their remembrance.

Five friends were reaping in a field when they saw a big goose-egg. They squabbled so much about it that they were tearing one another's hair. They agreed that they would own it in common, all five of them, and each was to sit on it in turn like a goose, and so hatch the gosling.. The Fjeld 043 is a collection of short stories by the Fjelder family. The story of a gosling who chipped an egg and said, "Herrings and brose, porridge and milk, all at once" The story was told to a group of five children.. "I've not known what it is to have a full meal since this changeling crept out of the egg-shell," said one of the men. "If they did not care for him, he didn't care for them," said another. "I was quite willing to be off," said the third man. "And I was off," the fourth man said.. A labourer was set to pick up stones from the field. He stuffed them all into his pocket. When he was done, the goodman asked him to come in and have something to eat. But he turned out his pockets and threw the stones in a heap. The goodman felt he ought to keep a workman who was so strong.. Grumblegizzard was sent to the king's grange. He was to be odd man, and help the lasses to bring in wood and water, and other small jobs. He alone ate all that was ready for the master and mistress and for the servants, and after all he was not half full. He then fell to chopping and hewing till the splinters flew about him.. Grumblegizzard went off to the smithy, and got a smith to help him to make an axe of fifteen pounds of iron. He then went into the forest and began to clear it; down toppled tall spruces and firs fit for masts. 'Twas not long before he had chopped up all that there was, both of firewood and timber, both planks and. "He has slain twelve men," said the king, "and he eats for twelve times twelve" "He laid a good load on a sledge, and put all the horses to it, but they could not stir the load from the spot" "The house was so shaken that it gave way at every joist, and he was within an ace of dragging the whole grange over on end". "For how many do you work, I should like to know?" said Grumblegizzard. "For twelve times twelve too," said the king. "Then go on and fight them," said his king. The king took his people with him to meet the foe. The battle was fought in the middle of a field.. The king wanted a mighty club to fight with. He forged a club of fifteen tons, and it took a hundred men to turn it on the anvil. He also made a scrip for food, and stuffed it full of ox-hides. The king then decided to kill the smith.. "Bide a bit, till I have had my dinner," said Grumblegizzard, as he threw himself down on the road, and fell to eating behind his great scrip. And so he toddled off down the hill with his scrip at his back and his club on his shoulder. When he had got so far that the enemy saw him, they sent out a. Grumblegizzard set off from the grange, with his scrip on his back and his club on his shoulder. But just then he got a bombshell right down his throat. He spat it out again; and then came a chain-shot and made its way into his butter-box, and another took the bit he was just going to eat from between his fingers. Then he got angry, and rose up, and took his club,. The Grumblegizzard asked his mother to give him a land-tax. She said she had never in her born days heard talk of any land- tax. He lost no time on the way, but when he got there, Old Nick was gone to serve a jury.. "That stood as fast as the old fir-tree," she said, "that grew outside the gate of hell, and was so big that fifteen men could scarcely span it when they held hands". "When he heard that Grumblegizzard had stridden off from his house with his big scrip full of money, he first of all beat and banged his mother, and then ran after him". "Here you have the land-tax," said Grumblegizzard, as he came to the king's grange, and dashed down the scripful of money. The king thanked him, and put a good face on it, and promised him good pay and a safe pass home if he cared to have. The Troll was said to dwell who had taken the king's grandfather's sword. Grumblegizzard got several loads of food into his big scrip, and set off again. But the Troll was not to be seen under bare sky, and the hill was fast shut. So he joined fellowship with some quarrymen, who were living at a hill farm. "I'm a pretty good trencherman myself," said Grumblegizzard. "But whoever has been here, has a sharper tooth, for he has eaten up bones and all". The Troll's old mother, asleep and snoring, hid the sword at the bottom of his bed. The king sent four horses to fetch the sword, but they could not stir it. The Troll's mother drank the sea dry, and so she burst. The sword stayed where it was, and the king could not move it an inch.. The king could not believe his eyes when he saw Grumblegizzard again. He promised him gold and green woods; and when GrumbleGizzard wanted more work, he said he had better set off for a haunted castle. The door blew back against the wall, and he saw nothing but a gaping jaw. Old Nick begged and prayed so prettily to be let go.. "This is a hard bargain," said Old Nick. And so he too had to promise to build a bridge over the Sound, so that folks could pass over it at all times of the year. So he got loose, and went home; but Grumblegizzard lay down to sleep, and slept till far on next day. So when the king came to see if he was hacked to pieces or torn to bits, he had to wade through heaps of money before. Old Nick stood on the bridge to take the toll he had bargained for. Grumblegizzard wanted the king with him to try the bridge, but he had no mind to do that. So he got up himself on a horse, and threw the fat milkmaid from the king's grange upon the pommel before him.. us: "You caught me once, and you shan't catch me again in a cleft stick;" and with that he flew off straight home to his old mother. Since then he has never been seen or heard in those parts. "If he hasn't come down again, there he is still hanging with his scrip between heaven and earth, to this very day"

The author was in a state of convalescence after a fever had brought him to the hospital. He had written home for a horse and sledge and his father's fur coat, but his letter could scarcely reach our valley before the day after Christmas. His comrades had all left town, and he knew no family with whom he could make himself at home during the holidays. He wrote to his parents, but they were too far away, and the horse could not be in town before New Year's Eve. The author's letter to them could not reach them before the end of the year, and they could not afford to send him back.. The two old maids I lodged with were certainly very kind and friendly people, and they had taken great care of me in the commencement of my illness. But the peculiar ways and habits of these ladies were too much of the old school to prove attractive to the fancies of youth. Their thoughts dwelt mostly on the past; and when they, as often might occur, related to me some stories of the town, its people and its customs, these stories reminded me, not only by their contents, but also by the simple, unaffected way in which they were rendered, of a past age. It was one of those old houses in Custom House Street, with deep windows, long dark passages and staircases, gloomy rooms and garrets.. "I tried to divert myself in my loneliness and melancholy mood by looking out at all the people who passed up and down the street," he writes. "The only relief to this kind of life was a pretty niece and some merry little cousins of hers, who always made me tell them fairy tales and stories" "The Swan," as it is still called, stood there, with its dark, reddish-brown walls, its pointed gables and towers, with weather-cocks and latticed windows," he says. "It was growing dusk. I could not distinguish the countenances any longer, but gazed across at the old building," he adds.. The Swan looked then, as now, a most respectable and sedate bird, with its gold ring round its neck, its spur-boots, and its wings stretched out as if to fly. I was about to plunge myself into reflection on imprisoned birds when I was disturbed by noise and laughter proceeding from some children in the adjoining room. "Will you not come in to us now at once? Old Mother Skau and my brother's little girls have come; they will perhaps amuse you a little. You are so fond of the dear children.". The room was furnished in the old style, with high-back, Russia leather chairs, and one of those settees which were intended for farthingales and straight up-and-down. The walls were adorned with oil paintings, portraits of stiff ladies with powdered coiffures, of bewigged Oldenborgians, and other redoubtable persons in mail and armour or red coats. The children do so like to tumble about here before the fire in the dusk of the evening, and Madam Skau does also enjoy a quiet little chat in the chimney corner," said Miss Cicely. "Oh, chat me here and chat me there! there is nothing you like yourself better than a little bit of gossip," said the old asthmatic lady.. "Come and sit down here and tell me how it fares with you," she said. "By my troth, you are nothing but skin and bones!" "I won't go; I am afraid of the brownies!" "Never mind, my dear, Stine says it only to get rid of you," said Miss Mette. "She dare not go into the hay-loft herself—the foolish old thing—in the dark, for she knows well enough she was frightened once by the brownie herself," said the aunt.. "Oh, is that you, Lieutenant? I did not know you. How pale you are! It is such a long time since I saw you!" shouted the children all at once, as they flocked round me. "But are you not going to say good evening to the Lieutenant, children?" they asked. "Now you must tell us something awfully jolly!" they demanded. "Do tell us about Buttercup and Goldentooth!" I had to tell them about the brownies at Vager and at Bure, who stole hay from each other, and who met at last with a load of hay on their backs.. "It served him right, the naughty brownie!" they shouted, and asked for another story. "Well," said I, "I will tell you the story of Peter Gynt and the trolls. The children clapped their hands in great joy and laughed heartily. "In the olden days there lived in Kvam a hunter whose name was Peter Gyn. He was always roaming about in the mountains after bears and elks. He had heard of a farm on Doorefell which was invaded by such a number of trolls every Christmas Eve that the people on the farm had to move out, and get shelter at their neighbours'. "Peter thought he should be able to clear the trolls out," says the author. "He had done such a thing before; and then he got leave to stay, and a pig's skin into the bargain" The trolls had a fiddler with them, and some began dancing, while others fell to eating the Christmas fare on the table. During this some of the trolls found the shoe Peter had made and began eating it. "Peter took out his awl and pitch and twine, and began making a big, big shoe, which it took the whole Pig's skin to make. He put a strong rope in for lacings, that he might pull the shoe tightly together, and. "The bear put his nose out from behind the fireplace, where he was lying, and smelt they were frying something. They thought it must belong to a very big foot. They all wanted to try it on at once, so they put a foot each into it" "Peter made haste and tightened the rope, took one of the handspikes and fastened the rope around it, and got them at last securely tied up in the shoe" "The trolls had to clear out at last, but Peter stayed and enjoyed himself with all the Christmas fare the whole week". "Some years afterwards, about Christmas time, Peter was out in the forest cutting wood for the holidays, when a troll came up to him and shouted 'Have you got that big pussy of yours, yet?' After that the trolls were not heard of there for many years. "Aunt Mette will tell you a story now," said Miss Cicely. "I don't know exactly what I shall tell you," said Aunt Mette, "but since we have commenced telling about the brownies, I think I will tellYou something about them. "Oh, yes, yes!" shouted the children. "You remember, of course, old Kari Gausdal, who came here and baked bread, and who always had so many tales to tell you" "Well, old. Kari told me that she was in service at the orphan asylum some years ago, and at. Kari was a servant at a house in the country. The other servants warned her not to light a fire before two o'clock. She did it anyway. The fire went out in a moment. Somebody appeared to be throwing the logs about on the hearth, but she could not see who it was. Kari was anything but chicken-hearted. If he comes in my way, why, by my faith, I will send him head over heels through the door. She said. 'I have nothing to do with that brownie of yours, but if he comes into my way I will kill him'. "I am getting so frightened!" said one of the children. "No, you must tell us some more stories, Lieutenant," said another. "I never feel afraid when you tell us anything," said the third. "You tell us such jolly tales," replied the fourth. "And so I did," said Kari Gausdal, "and the children went on to tell their own stories." "And from that time nobody saw or heard the brownie in the asylum," said Gausdale. "But from that point on, the children never heard of him again.". "There was, once upon a time," says the author, "a lassie who was sent up into the hay-loft with the cream porridge for the brownie" The story was told to the children by the author's niece, Lizzie, who was besieged by the children and had to promise to do the singing. The children asked the author to tell them a story about the Halling dance. The author said he was going to sing it, but the children wouldn't let him off.. She ate the porridge herself, and the melted butter in the bargain, and went up into the hay-loft with the plain oatmeal porridge and sour milk, in a pig's trough instead. 'There, that's good enough for you, Master Brownie,' she said. But no sooner had she spoken the words than the brownie stood right before her, seized her. The children were soon quiet, and Mother Skau commenced as follows: "You hear a great deal about brownies and fairies and such like beings, but I don't believe there is much in it. I have neither seen one nor the other. But old Stine out in the kitchen there, she says she has seen the brownie" The children romped about the room in uproarious joy. But as long as they danced, the "brownie sang," said Cousin Lizzie, "to the tune of the Halling." The children then began to sing. The story ended with the children singing to the tune, and the children dancing.. People said there was a brownie in the house. Well, it so happened that Stine and the cook were sitting in their room one evening, mending and darning their things. They heard a terrible crash down stairs in the kitchen, and Stine shouted, 'Lor' bless and preserve us! it must be the brownie' When they opened the kitchen door they found all the crockery on the floor, but none of it broken. The brownie was standing on the big kitchen table with his red cap on, and hurling one dish after the other on to the floor. He was laughing in great glee. Stine was so frightened she dared scarcely move a foot.. The cook had heard that the brownies could sometimes be tricked into moving into another house when anybody would tell them of a very quiet place. She took courage and spoke to him and told him he ought to remove to the tinman's over the way, where it was so very quiet and pleasant. He seemed to feel quite at home there, although they were hammering and tapping away there all day. But people said that the gude-wife put a dish of porridge up in the garret for him every Thursday evening, and it's no wonder they got on well and became rich when they had a brownie in the house. Stine believed he brought things to them.. "My mother, who, by the way, was a truthful woman, told a story which happened here in the town one Christmas Eve," said Mother Skau. "Let us hear it, Madame Skau," said I. "Yes, tell, tell," cried the children. "When my mother still was in her teens, she used sometimes to visit a widow whom she knew, and whose name was Madame Evensen," she said. "Whether it was the brownie or not who really helped them, I cannot say," she added. "I know it is true, for an untrue word never passed her lips," replied I.. A woman thought she would go to the morning service on the Christmas Day. She left out some coffee with the girl before she went to bed, that she might get a cup next morning. When she woke, the moon was shining into the room, but the clock had stopped. She took her hymn-book and started for church. But when she went inside, she thought that the people were so pale and so strange. They looked exactly as if they were all dead. She must have overslept herself! She called the girl and told her to get the coffee ready, while she dressed herself. The street was very quiet; she did not meet a single person on her way to church. She sat down in her customary seat in one of the pews.. She did not know any of them, but there were several of them she seemed to recollect having seen before. When the minister came into the pulpit, she saw that he was not one of the ministers in the town, but a tall, pale man. He preached very nicely indeed, and there was not the usual noisy coughing and hawking which you always hear at the morning services on a Christmas Day. It was so quiet, you could have heard a needle drop on the floor. She began to feel quite uneasy and uncomfortable. A female who sat next to her leant towards her and whispered in her ear, 'Throw the cloak loosely around you and go, because if you wait here till the service is over. "She got away from them safe enough; only listen! When the widow heard the voice of the person next to her, she turned round to look at her," says the author. "She recognized her; it was her neighbour who died many years ago," he says. "When she came out on the steps, she felt that they had got hold of her cloak," he adds. "So she let it go and left it in their clutches, while she hurried home as quickly as she could" The next day the people found the cloak lying on the Steps, but it was torn into a thousand pieces. "By the time she got inside she was nearly half dead," says author. 'She was that frightened.. The children, who had expressed considerable fear and uneasiness during the latter part of the story, declared they would not hear any more such terrible stories. The lights, the Christmas cake, the jellies, the tarts and the wine soon chased away the horrible ghost story and all fear from their minds. Finally, our thoughts took a flight towards something more substantial, on the appearance of the Christmas porridge and the roast ribs of pork. The children had crept up into the sofa and on the chairs, but still they thought they felt somebody plucking at them from underneath the table. Suddenly the lights were brought in, and we discovered then, to our great amusement, that the children had put their legs on to the table, and were playing.. The author and his wife had a very uneasy night, and broke up early. He says he got mixed up with fairies, fairies and ghosts the whole night. The minister was in the pulpit; it was my grandfather, who died when I was a little boy. He made a somersault right into the middle of the church, and the surplice flew one way and the collar another. The church was lighted up, and when I came inside I saw it was our own church up in the valley. There were nobody there but peasants in their red caps, soldiers in full uniform.. The parson was in the midst of a wild dance. A big tall peasant came towards me and took me by the shoulder and said, "You'll have to join us, my lad!" The parson awoke and could scarcely believe his eyes when he saw the same peasant whom he had seen in my dream leaning over him. There he was, with the red cap down over his ears, a big fur coat over his arm, and a pair of big eyes looking fixedly at me. "There lies the parson, and here am I," he said, with one of his well-known airs.. "But, good heavens! is that you, Thor?" I shouted in great joy. It was indeed my father's man, a splendid specimen of a Norwegian peasant. "I came with your favourite, the bay mare. I had to take your father down to Næs, and then he says to me, 'Thor,' says he, 'it isn't very far to town from here' Just take the baymare and run down and see how the Lieutenant is, and if he is well and can come back with you, you must bring him back along with.
