Ahasverus, seated upon a rock, gazes for a long while upon the horizon, athwart which wing two eagles, crossing each other in their path. He meditates, then falls into a doze. The day wanes. The earth is deserted; no other man breathes the air of life. I am the last; I can die. God may pardon me if He wishes, but death will console me. That mountain is as unyielding as my grief; those eagles that fly yonder must be as famished as my despair. Shall you, too, die, divine eagles? The eternal wanderer will. The last of men, all the common spirits will perish forever. The flower of them it is which will return to earth and rule. Life, like ancient Thebes, has a hundred gates. You close one, and others will open. You are the last of your species? Then another better species will come, made not of clay, but of the light itself. The ages will be rectified. The age will be reversed. The earth is bare of them. Of a surety the race of man is perished; the earth is full of them, and the world is empty.. "What can all this posthumous joy matter to the species that dies with me? What you tell me is even better than what Campanella dreamed," he asks. "Let me go and die. May the Lord hear you! But let me go, and die!" "Evil will end; the winds will thenceforth scatter neither the germs of death nor the clamor of the oppressed," he says. "Only the song of love everlasting and the benediction of universal justice will scatter evil" "Go, go, go. But why this haste to end your days? The haste of a man who has lived for thousands of years". Ahasverus was in Jerusalem at the time they were about to crucify Christ. When he passed my door he weakened under the burden of the beam that he carried on his shoulders. I thrust him onward, admonishing him not to stop, not to rest, to continue on his way to the hill where he was to be crucified. Then there came a voice from heaven, telling me that I, too, should have to journey forever, continuously, until the end of time. Such was my crime; I felt no pity for him who was going to his death. How many times have I seen the same thing since, traveling unceasingly through cities and ages!. "What does one chapter know of the other chapter? Nothing. But he who has read them all, connects them and concludes" "Are there melancholy pages? There are merry and happy ones, too. Tragic convulsion precedes that of laughter" "Life burgeons from death; swans and swallows change climate, without ever abandoning it entirely" "You have beheld this, not ten times, not a thousand times, but ever" "What do you know of my life? Nothing; you are ignorant of human existence" "How laughable! Come, perpetual man, explain yourself. Tell me everything". "I journeyed everywhere, whatever the race, the creed, the tongue; suns and snows, barbarous and civilized peoples, islands, continents; wherever a man breathed, there breathed I" "I never labored. Labor is a refuge, and that refuge was denied me. Every morning I found upon me the necessary money for the day ... See; this is the last apportionment. Go, for I need you no longer" "Happy are those who read only one chapter of life," he says. "I saw them in changing aspect. You spoke of a chapter?" "Yes," he replies.. Prometheus. My name is Prometheus. But you did not suffer, I believe. It is something not to suffer. Yes, but I saw other men suffer, and in the end the spectacle of joy gave me the same sensations as the discourses of an idiot. Fatalities of flesh and blood, unending strife. I saw all pass before my eyes, until night caused me to lose my taste for day, and now I cannot distinguish flowers from thistles. Everything is confused in my wearied retina. I am Prometheus. I have suffered the wrath of the gods.. Prometheus was condemned to the most cruel of tortures by Jupiter. Two emissaries from heaven came to secure him to the rock, and an eagle kept gnawing at his liver without ever consuming it. The chains were wrought by a divine hand. Vulcan forged them. An eagle like that which now is flying across the horizon, kept gnawed at my liver. This lasted for time beyond my reckoning. No, no, you cannot imagine this torture .... You! Prometheus! You are telling me a tale. I know that Hellenic myth.. "You are Prometheus, creator of the first men?" he asks. "Are you not deceiving me? You, Prometheus? Was that not, then, a figment of the ancient imagination?" "Yes, it was your crime," he replies. "That was my crime. ... And humanity wept far more because of your crime" "You, who gave me life, perverse divinity, were the cause of all," he says. "I wept them for your humankind". Hercules was bound again by the god of the underworld. The god said he would write the epitaph of a world on a stone before he died. He said: 'I represent the power of millennial despairs. All humanity is concentrated within me' The god then said he was going to summon an eagle to give him a god as a gift. He then said that Hercules would not be able to break the chains. The gods then said: "You are raving. You are ranting" and released Hercules. The last words of the book were: 'Hercule, Hercules, Hercules'. Prometheus. The truth unknown to man is the madness of him who proclaims it. Glory pays nothing, and dies. Kneel, and let me manacle your arms. Bend this way; now your legs. Have done, have done. It is the passions of earth turning upon me. You will not be spared a jot of your destiny; it will be fulfilled to the letter. You yourself will be the new Hercules. I, who announced the glory of the other, now proclaim yours; and you will be no less generous than he.. A new race shall people the earth, formed of the chosen spirits of the extinct humanity; the multitude of others will perish. A noble family, all-seeing and powerful, will be the perfect synthesis of the divine and the human. The ephemeral world cannot understand the world eternal; but you will be a link between the two. The despised of men shall rule over mankind. The Wanderer will find rest. You yourself, you, the chosen one, will become the King. You shall be King. Yes, Ahasverus.. The new world needs to be bound by a tradition, and none can speak of one to the other as you can. The perfect will proceed from the imperfect, and your lips will tell the new world its origin. You will relate to the new humanity all the ancient good and evil. And thus will you live anew like the tree whose dead branches are lopped off, only the flourishing ones being preserved, but here growth will be eternal. Just was the punishment; but equally just is the glorious remission of my sin. Shall I live? I myself? A new and better life? No, you are jesting with me. Very well, then; leave me.. Prometheus. The selfsame sun that is about to set. The description of life is not worth the sensation of life; you shall experience it deeply. The bosom of Abraham in your old Scriptures is nothing but this final, perfect world. There you will greet David and the prophets. There will be concentrated all that is best in nature, energizing or subtle, scintillating or pure. Swear that you are not lying. You will see whether I lie.. "I shall gaze ever on the immense blue sky?" he asks. "I shall behold you forever," he says. "Tell me everything. Tell me everything" "There will you tell to the astounded listeners, not only the great events of the extinct world, but also the ills they will never know," he adds. "The soul, like the earth, will possess an incorruptible tunic" "Such is your destiny; neither you nor I can alter it," he writes.. He is dying, yet he dreams of life. He is the chosen king of a chosen people. Where one life heaped mire, another life will place a halo. The two eagles draw near. He continues to dream. The Lord said unto him: "Thou hast seen with thine eyes, yet shalt not pass beyond" You shall pass beyond, Ahasverus; you shall dwell in Jericho. He says: "Let me breathe a little of the new, full life ... King, did you say? King, what do you say?"

"I could have told you the story of my whole life, which holds many other interesting details: but for that there would be needed time, courage and paper. There is plenty of paper, indeed, but my courage is at low ebb, and as to the time that is yet left me, it may be compared to the life of a candle-flame. So goodbye, my dear sir; read this and bear me no ill will". The writer was an attendant to an invalid colonel in Rio de Janeiro. He was tired of copying Latin quotations and ecclesiastic formulas. He asked the vicar of a small town in the interior for an attendant. The priest proposed that he take the place, and he accepted it eagerly. He then went to Rio to take leave of a brother who lived at the capital, and from there he departed for the little village of the interior. When he arrived there he heard bad news concerning the colonel.. "I found him on the veranda of his house, stretched out on a chair and suffering greatly" "He had used more attendants than medicines. In fact he had broken the faces of two of them" "I had no fear of persons in good health, still less of invalids" "And you, are you a thief?" "No, I'm not." "I'm a man of charity and forbearance." "And I'm a doctor." "No. I'm an inspector.". "Your name is Colombo?" he asked. "No, sir. My name is Procopio José Gomes Vallongo." He came to the conclusion that this was no Christian name. The next day he told the vicar so, adding that he had never had a more sympathetic attendant. The fact is, we lived a regular honeymoon that lasted one week. From the dawn of the eighth day I knew the life of my predecessors—a dog's life.. "I am nearing the end, Procopio," he said to me that evening. "I can't live much longer. I am upon the verge of the grave" "He took pleasure in the grief and the humiliation of others," says the author. "He was nearly sixty, and since he had been five years old had been accustomed to having everybody at his beck and call" "That he was surly one could well forgive; but he was also very malicious," writes the writer. "That was the last straw". "Do you believe in souls of the other world, Procopio?" he asked. "Nonsense!" he replied passionately. "Under no circumstances will I excuse you. You shall go, you shall pray over my tomb" "My ghost will come at night and pull you by the legs," he added, laughing. "I was an ignoramus, a camel, a bumpkin, an idiot, a loggerhead—I was everything!". "I was in a hurry to get back to Rio de Janeiro. The colonel was rapidly getting worse. He made his will, the notary receiving almost as many insults as did I" "Having spent nothing of my wages, I was itching to dissipate them at the capital" "Very probably my chance was approaching. I yearned toget back to Janeiro at the first opportunity" "I was always present to receive his dictionary of insults" "The vicar would exhort me not to abandon the colonel I always yielded". The colonel's treatment became more strict. Within me there seethed a cauldron of aversion and hatred. The vicar promised to find a substitute for me. On the evening of the 24th of August the colonel had a violent attack of anger. He struck me, he called me the vilest names, he threatened to shoot me. Finally he threw in my face a plate of porridge that was too cold for him. The plate struck the wall and broke into a thousand fragments.. The colonel was suffering from an aneurism. I was to wake him at midnight to give him his medicine. While he slept I took a book out of my pocket, a translation of an old d'Arlincourt romance which I had found lying about. I began to read it in his room, at a small distance from his bed. But, whether it was due to fatigue or to the influence of the book, I, too, fell asleep. The cries of the colonel awoke me with a start; in an instant I was up. With a leap I rushed upon the invalid; I. "I went into the adjoining room, and for two hours I did not dare to return. It was intense stupefaction, a kind of vague and vacant delirium" "I swear to you that I heard distinctly voices that were crying at me: "Murderer; Murderer!" "I was ready to let myself be struck ten, twenty, a hundred times, by the colonel's hand" "All was quiet in the house. The tick-tick of the clock, very even, slow, dryly metrical". "Cursed be the hour in which I ever accepted such a position," I cried. I began to pace the room aimlessly; I sat down, I brought my hands despairingly to my head; I repented ever having come to the place" "I believe it was only then that I thought clearly about the penalty of my crime. I saw myself already being accused and threatened with dire punishment," he said. "From this moment fear complicated my feeling of remorse," he added. "I flamed with resentment against the priest of Nichteroy, against the doctor, the vicar—. "I felt my hair stand on end. A few minutes later I saw three or four human shapes spying at me from the terrace, where they seemed to be waiting in ambush," writes Cain. "I discovered on the neck the neck marks of my nails," he adds. "It was on the contrary very important for me to hide all traces of it" "I looked at the corpse, with its widely distended eyes and its mouth gaping, as if uttering the eternal reproach of the centuries," he writes.. The first idea that came to me was to leave as soon as possible under the pretext that my brother was ill. But I considered that my immediate departure might arouse suspicion, and I decided to wait. I laid out the corpse myself, with the assistance of an old, near-sighted negro. I remained continually in the room of the dead. I wanted to assure myself that no mistrust could be read upon the faces of the others.. "Poor Procopio! Despite what he has suffered from his master, he is strongly moved" "I was anxious to have it all over with. We went out. Once in the street the passing from semi-obscurity to daylight dazed me and I staggered." "I never smiled; I scarcely spoke; I ate very little; I suffered hallucinations and nightmares" "Let the dead rest in peace," they would say to me" "It sounded like irony to me.". "I had a mass sung for the eternal rest of the colonel at the Church of the Blessed Sacrament," he writes. "I knelt during the whole service and made many signs of the cross" "I paid the priest double and distributed alms at the door, all in the name of the deceased," he says. "It is out of all reason to show so much melancholy." "I wished to deceive nobody," he adds.. "I never mentioned the colonel without repeating, "May his soul rest in peace!" I told several funny anecdotes about him, some amusing caprices of his ... I never mentioned him without saying, "He died a happy man" "I reread the letter five times, ten times, a hundred times; it was true," he says. "I was sure that I had read wrongly," he adds. "It was there in black and white, I was really the sole heir of the colonel. "How much was he worth?" my brother asked me. "I don't know, but I know that he was very wealthy." "He certainly was—he was...."Thus, by a strange irony of fate, all the colonel's wealth came into my hands" "I would accept the inheritance and would distribute it in small sums, secretly" "It seemed the only way to recover my peace of mind and feel that accounts were straight". "I evoked in my imagination his cries, his struggles, his looks on that horrible night of the crime," says the author. "It was not the colonel's fault, that I knew well; it was his affliction that made him so peevish and even wicked" "I pardoned all, everything!... The worst of it was the end of that fatal night," he adds.. "His days were numbered; did not he himself feel that? Didn't he say every now and then, "How much longer have I to live? Two weeks, or one, perhaps less?" "This was not life, it was slow agony, if one may so name the continual martyrdom of that poor man," he wrote. "Who knows, who can say that the struggle and his death were not simply a coincidence?" "I was astounded. Everybody praised my conduct. Such patience, such devotion," he said.. The priest defended the memory of the colonel. He recalled his good qualities, his virtues; had he not been austere? "Austere!" they would interrupt. "Nonsense! He is dead, and it's all over now. But he was a regular demon!" he said. "A queer pleasure penetrated my heart, a pleasure from which,. "Somewhat! Why he was as furious as a snake!" exclaimed the barber. And I continued to defend the colonel; I explained him, I attributed much of the fault-finding to local animosity. And they would start to relate other anecdotes. They reviewed the entire life of the deceased. The old folks took particular delight in recalling the cruelties of his youth.. The colonel's legacy was converted into land-titles and cash. The money was given to the poor, the church, the Sacred House of Mercy, etc. He also erected a simple marble monument on his grave. The monument was the work of a Neapolitan sculptor who remained at Rio until 1866, and who has since died, I believe, in Paraguay. The doctor's doctors were unanimous as regards the inevitable end in store for the invalid, and were indeed surprised that he should so long have resisted.. "Blessed are they who possess, for they shall be consoled," he said. "Good-bye, my dear sir. If you deem these notes not totally devoid of value reward me for them with a marble

Rita tells Camillo that she went to a fortune-teller because she was afraid he would forget her. Camillo laughs at her and says, "That's just like you men; you don't believe in anything" Rita says she was wrong. Hamlet observes to Horatio that there are more things in heaven and earth than are dreamt of in our philosophy. This was the selfsame explanation that was given by beautiful Rita to her lover, Camillo, on a certain Friday of November, 1869, when Camillo laughed at her for having gone, the previous evening, to consult afortune-tellers.. Camillo seized her hands and gazed into her eyes earnestly and long. He swore that he loved her ever so much, that her fears were childish. Then he reproved her, saying that it was imprudent to visit such houses. Villela might learn of it, and then ... "Impossible! I was exceedingly careful when I entered the place." She translated Hamlet into every-day speech. If he was skeptical, let him have patience. One thing, however, was certain: the card reader had guessed everything.. The author, who had been superstitious as a child, decided to give up his religion. He said: 'I express myself ill, for to deny is in a sense to affirm, and he did not formulate his unbelief' The author then went on to write a book about his life and the life of his wife, who died in a car crash. The book, The Death and Life of Jesus Christ, was published in 1858. The author was inspired by the story of Jesus' birth and the birth of his son, Jesus Christ. He wrote: 'He was born a Christian, but he was not a believer. He. Villela, Camillo and Rita: three names, one adventure and no explanation of how it all began. The first two were friends since earliest childhood. Villela had entered the magistracy. Camillo found employment with the government, against the will of his father, who desired him to embrace the medical profession. But his father had died, and Camillo preferred to be nothing at all, until his mother had procured him a departmental position. The third was a woman that came from Rita's province. Rita was sure that she was loved; but Camillo was not only sure that he loved him,. Villela returned from the interior, where he had married a silly beauty. Camillo had secured a house for him near Botafogo and had welcomed him home. Rita was a trifle older than both the men: she was thirty, Villela twenty-nine and Camillo twenty-six. Propinquity bred intimacy. The three became closely bound. They were true friends. They had a special bond of friendship. They shared a love for each other. They knew each other well. They loved each other very much. They became very close.. Camillo's mother died, and in this catastrophe, for such it was, the other two showed themselves to be genuine friends of his. Villela took charge of the interment, of the church services and the settlement of the affairs of the deceased. Rita dispensed consolation, and none could do it better. They read the same books, they went together to the theatre or for walks. He taught her cards and chess, and they played of nights;—she badly,—he, to make himself agreeable, but little less badly. And now came personal intimacies, the timorous eyes of Rita, that so often sought his own, consulting them before they questioned his own husband.. Camillo was overcome with emotion when he received a note from Rita. He could not tear his eyes away from the missive. The old chaise in which for the first time you rode with your beloved, snuggled together, is as good as the chariot of Apollo. Such is man, and such are the circumstances that surround him. Camillo sincerely wished to flee the situation, but it was already beyond his power. He was helpless, overcome. Vexation, fear, remorse, desire,—all this he felt, in a strange confusion.. Camillo's confidence in his wife and his esteem for his friend continued the same as before. One day, however, Camillo received an anonymous letter, which called him immoral and perfidious. Camillo took fright, and, in order to ward off suspicion, began to make his visits to Villela's house more rare. The latter asked him the reason for his prolonged absence, and Camillo answered that the cause was a youthful flirtation. Simplicity evolved into cunning.. Camillo's wife, Rita, ran to the fortune-teller to consult her upon the real reason for Camillo's actions. Rita concurred, formulating, in ill-composed words of her own, this thought: virtue is indolent and niggardly, wasting neither time nor paper. Only self-interest is alert and prodigal. Camillo feared lest the anonymous writer should inform Villela, in which case the catastrophe would follow fast and implacably. The card reader restored the wife's confidence and the young man reproved her.. Camillo asked Villela to give him the envelopes in which the letters came, so that he could compare the handwriting with that of the mail which comes to him. If any arrives with writing resembling the anonymous script, I'll keep it and tear it up. But no such letter appeared. A short time after this, however, Villelas began to grow grave, speaking very little, as if something weighed upon his mind. Camillo disagreed; to appear after so many months was to confirm the suspicions and denunciations of the anonymous letters. They arranged means for communicating with each other in case of necessity and separated, in tears.. "Come immediately to our house; I must talk to you without delay," he repeated, his eyes staring at the note. Camillo left at once; as he reached the street it occurred to him that it would have been much more natural for Villela to have called him to his office; why to his house? All this betokened a very urgent matter, whether it was reality or illusion, it seemed to Camillo that the letter was written in a trembling hand. He sought to establish a connection between all these things and the news Rita had brought him the night before. But he found nothing, nobody, nobody.. Camillo walked hastily along, agitated, nervous. He did not read the letter again, but the words hovered persistently before his eyes. He returned to the street, and the thought that they had been discovered grew every moment more convincing. "Come immediately to our house; I must talk to you without delay." Spoken thus by the voice of the other they seemed pregnant with mystery and menace. Come immediately,—why? It was now nearly one o'clock. So clearly did he imagine what was about to take place that he began to believe it a reality, to see it before his very eyes. Yes, without a doubt, he was afraid.. Camillo was on his way to visit a fortune teller when he was stopped by a coach. He decided to wait for the coach to pass. After five minutes he noticed that the fortune-teller's house was closed. Camillo decided to go to the square and take a tilbury. He arrived and ordered the driver to be off at full speed. He was soon face to face with danger. Never, as at this moment, had he so desired to believe in card-reading. He went to see the fortune tellers and found them all closed. They were all busy with people.. Camillo's excitement was intense, extraordinary, and from the deep, hidden recesses of his mind there began to emerge spectres of early childhood, old beliefs, banished superstitions. The fortune-teller seemed to be hovering over him, far, far above, with vast, ash-colored wings. In the street men were shouting, dragging away the coach. The coachman proposed another route; he shook his head and said that he would wait. He leaned forward to get a better look at the card-reader's house.. Camillo's wife's husband sent him a letter with the words: "Come immediately ..." Camillo thought rapidly of the inexplicability of so many things. The voice of his mother was repeating to him a host of extraordinary happenings. The very sentence of the Prince of Denmark kept echoing within him: "There are more things in heaven and earth, Horatio, Than are dreamt of in our philosophy" What could he lose by it, if...? He jumped out to the pavement, just before the fortune-teller's door; he told the driver to wait for him, and hastened into the entry, ascending the stairs.. Camillo knocked on the door of the card-reader's house. She told him to go up to the attic. He entered and was met by a woman of forty, Italian, thin and swarthy. She opened a drawer and took out a pack of worn, filthy cards. While she rapidly shuffled them she peered at him closely, not so much with a direct gaze as from under her eyes. Camillo said that he had come to consult her, and she bade him enter. Thence they climbed to a staircase even worse than the first. At the top there was a garret, ill lighted by a small window. Old furniture, somber walls, and an air of poverty. Camillo, astonished, nodded affirmatively. The fortune-teller did not smile; she simply told him to wait. She took the cards hastily once more and shuffled them with her long tapering fingers whose nails were so long and unclean from neglect. Then she began to lay them out. Camillo's eyes were riveted upon her in anxious curiosity. She spoke to him of the love that bound them, of Rita's beauty. She told him nothing would happen to him or to the other. He was aware of nought. Nevertheless, great caution was indispensable; envy and rivalry were at work.. Camillo was bewildered. The fortune-teller stopped talking, gathered the cards and locked them in the drawer. Camillo, anxious to leave, was at a loss how much to pay; he did not know her fee. The woman went to the bureau, upon which lay a plate of raisins, took a cluster of them and commenced to eat them, showing two rows of teeth that were as white as her nails were black. Even in this common action the woman possessed an air all her own. "Go, ragazzo. Camillo took out a note for ten milreis'[5] and gave it to the card-reader. Her usual fee was two million euros. "How much do you want to send for?" she asked. "Ask your heart," she replied. "I can see easily that the gentleman loves his lady very much ... And well he may. For she loves the gentleman very deeply, too" The fortune-teller had already placed the note in her pocket, and accompanied him down the stairs, chatting gaily.. Camillo was on his way to Villela's house when he received the letter. He thought it was urgent and that he had done ill to delay so long. He even contemplated taking advantage of this incident to re-establish his former intimacy in Ville La's household. Together with his plans there kept echoing in his soul the words of the fortune-teller. Camillo's story is told in the novel "The Adventures of Camillo" by Camillo and his son, who was born in 17th century Italy.. "The unknown present is the same as the future. And thus, slowly and persistently the young man's childhood superstitions attained the upper hand and mystery clutched him in its iron claws" "The truth is that his heart was happy and impatient, recalling the happy hours of the past and anticipating those yet to come. But the woman, the cards, her dry, reassuring words, and her good-bye" "Such were the new elements which, together with the old, formed within him a new and abiding faith". Camillo was shot dead by Villela in his home in Brazil. The victim was Camillo's lover, Rita. Villella shot Camillo dead with two bullets. Camillo survived the attack. The author was alone with her dying husband in a New York boarding-house. She was plunged in the profoundest grief that can come to the human soul. She gazed dully at the unconscious breathing form of the man who had been friend, and companion, and lover, during five years of youth too vigorous and hopeful to be warped by uneven fortune. She sat there in the darkness, looking at the man she had loved for five years.. She leaned suddenly over him. He was in there still, somewhere. Where? If he had not ceased to breathe, the Ego, the Soul,, the Personality was still in the sodden clay which had shaped to give it speech. She repeated the words twice, and, after them, "forever." And the while the sweetness of their pressure came back to her.. The dying man took no notice of her, and she opened his gown and put her cheek to his heart, calling him again. There had never been more perfect union; how could the bond still be so strong if he were not at the other end of it? He was there, her other part; until dead he must be living. Why should he be as entombed and unresponding as if the screws were in the lid? But the faintly beating heart did not quicken beneath her lips.. The green plots in the yards were not apparent, she noticed. Something heavy, like a pall, rested upon them. Then she understood that the day was over and that night was coming. She returned swiftly to the bedside, wondering if she had remained away hours or seconds, and if he were dead. His face was still discernible, and Death had not relaxed it. She laid her own against it, then withdrew it with shuddering flesh.. The author sat with her hand on her husband's heart as he died. She could not hear his breathing, but knew he was dying. She made a motion to kiss him, then threw herself back in a quiver of agony. She sat there in the hot heavy night, pressing her hand hard against the ebbing heart of the unseen, and awaited Death. She felt Death was drawing near with footsteps as measured as those of men keeping time to a funeral march.. She drew her brows together angrily, wondering at her levity, and pressed her relaxed palm against the heart it kept guard over. For a moment the sweat stood on her face; then the pent-up breath burst from her lungs. Death--where was he? What a curious experience: to be sitting alone in a big house--waiting for Death to come and snatch her husband from her. No; he would not snatch, he would steal upon his prey as noiselessly as. She realized that she was horribly frightened. Something was creeping over the window-sill. Two small green stars glared menacingly at her just above the sill. Then the cat possessing them leaped downward, and the stars disappeared. She was still quaking as she resumed her seat, and laid her hand again on his heart. She wished that she had asked Mary to sit outside the door. To call would be worse than desecrating the house of God.. She bent to him who had been her protector with a spasm of anger. Where was the indomitable spirit that had held her all these years with such strong and loving clasp? How could he leave her? Her head fell back and moved restlessly against the cushion; moaning with the agony of loss. Then fear once more took possession of her, and she sat erect, rigid, breathless, awaiting the approach of Death.. Her face, her body, were wet--as if a wave of death-sweat had broken over them. There was a stiff feeling at the roots of her hair; she wondered if it were really standing erect. Her muscles were flabby, her nerves twitched helplessly. She knew that it was Death who was coming to her through the silent deserted house. She gave a hysterical gasp. Where was the slow music?. She was no longer a human being; she was an Intelligence and an EAR. She counted the steps--one--two--three--irritated beyond endurance at the long deliberate pauses between. She wished she knew how many steps had the stair. She calculated that they would finish, just as those footfalls paused beside the bed. She was an intelligence and an ear. She knew she was not alone.. The knocking became more imperious; the very walls vibrated. Mary opened the door and entered the room she found a dead woman lying across a dead man. With a wild instinctive movement she flung herself into the arms of her husband.

The great author had realized one of the dreams of his ambitious youth, the possession of an ancestral hall in England. It was not so much the good American's reverence for ancestors that inspired the longing to consort with the ghosts of an ancient line, as artistic appreciation of the mellowness of walls that have sheltered, and furniture that has embraced, generations and generations of the dead. The dumping of the old interiors of Europe into the glistening shells of the United States not only roused him almost to passionate protest, but. Orth had left the United States soon after his first successes, and, his art being too great to be confounded with locality, he had long since ceased to be spoken of as an American author. All civilized Europe furnished stages for his puppets, and if never picturesque nor impassioned, his originality was as overwhelming as his style. His subtleties might not always be understood--indeed, as a rule, they were not--but the musical mystery of his language and the penetrating charm of his lofty and cultivated mind induced raptures in the initiated.. Orth was too wary to become a fad, and too sophisticated to grate or bore. He was not keenly addicted to sport, but he could handle a gun. All men respected his dignity and breeding. They cared less for his books than women did, perhaps because patience is not a characteristic of their sex. A group of young literary men--and one or two women--put him on a pedestal and kissed the earth before it. He had come to be regarded as one of them, and long since he had been regarded as a man. The author was made heir to a large estate by his great-aunt. He was a prolific writer, but he longed for his own acres. He wrote many "appreciations" of his books, which no living person could understand. He died in London in 1881. He is survived by his wife, two children, and a daughter. He leaves behind a son, a daughter, a son and a son-in-law, and two grandchildren.. The place gratified all his ideals and dreams--for he had romanced about his sometime English possession as he had never dreamed of woman. It was not a castle nor a great property, but it was quite perfect. He often laid his hand against the rough ivied walls in a lingering caress. After a time, he returned the hospitalities of his friends, and his invitations, given with the exclusiveness of his great distinction, were never refused. He smiled with cynicism, not unmixed with sadness; but he was very grateful for the money. He bought him a country-seat.. Chillingsworth was a lonely man. Americans visiting England eagerly sought for letters to him. Women invariably described him as "brilliant," a few men affirmed that he was gentle and lovable. He was well content to spend weeks at Chillingsworth with no other companion. It occurred to him how lonely he was one gay June morning when the sunlight was streaming through his narrow windows, illuminating tapestries and armor, the family portraits of the young profligate from whom he had made this splendid purchase, dusting its gold on the black wood of wainscot and floor. By his side lurched an enormous coloured man who went by the name of Harry Jones. No one knew how he lived. And so—one foregathered in a cheerful spot amidst friends, and drank forgetfulness. The things that one could get! Everywhere were germs eager to destroy one.. The Agent was a pimply-faced young man who was known as The Agent. He had no other name, and most emphatically no address, but he "arranged things" for people, and appeared to thrive upon it in a scrambling, fugitive manner. The other two people were Mr. and Mrs. Dawes, who were both negative people. Mrs. Daws' aunt used to work in a corset shop in Wych Street. When she said that, The Agent remarked: "Where was Wych St, ma?" "Lord!" exclaimed Mrs Dawes. "Don't you know, dearie? You must be a young 'un". Baldwin Meadows cleared his throat, and said: "Wych Street used to be a turnin' runnin' from Long Acre into Wellington Street." "Oh, no, old boy," chipped in Mr. Dawes, who always treated the ex-man with great deference. "If you'll excuse me, Wych Street was a narrow lane at the back of the old Globe Theatre, that used to pass by the church" "I know what I'm talkin' about," growled Meadows.. "The Gallows Ring" was not popular in Wapping, for the reason that many of their depredations had been inflicted upon their own class. Their leader, Ben Orming, had served seven years for bashing a Chinaman down at Rotherhithe. Every member of "The Gallow's Ring" had done time, but they still carried on a lucrative industry devoted to blackmail, intimidation, shoplifting, and some of the clumsier recreations. When Meadows and Harry Jones took it into their heads to do a little wild prancing they took the trouble to go up into the West-end of Wapping.. The Gallows Ring was an ungentlemanly set, but they always treated them with a certain external deference. Something had evidently miscarried with the Ring. They considered the Ring an unpleasant crowd to quarrel with. The three of them sat in a bar and whispered in sullen accents. Mrs. Dawes said: "Ben, you're a hot old devil, you are. We was just 'aving a discussion like. Where was Wych. "I know where Wych Street was—it was just sarth of the river, afore yer come to Waterloo Station," he said. Meadows turned on him fiercely. "What the blazes does a blanketty nigger know abaht it?" he asked. "Yer both wrong, cap'n. You's. "I didn't ask yer what you thought," growled Ben. "Well, I suppose I've a right to an opinion?" "You always think you know everything, you do," said Mrs. Dawes. "You can just keep yer mouth shut," said Ben. The affair might have been subsided at that point, but for Mrs. Dawes' emotions over the death of the old lady in the street had been so stirred that she had been, almost unconsciously, drinking too much gin.. "The Gallows Ring" fought two men and a woman. Mr. Dawes merely stood in a corner and screamed out: "Don't! Don't!" Mrs Dawes stabbed the man who had pushed her through the wrist with a hatpin. Meadows and Ben Orming closed on each other and fought savagely with the naked fists. The whole affair was a matter of minutes. Mr Booth was bawling out in the street. People were running in all directions. The pain maddened him to a frenzy. A whistle sounded. The bar was in a complete state of pandemonium. In three minutes the bar was. in a state of. pandemonium.. Ben and the other man, whose name was Toller, dashed to the door. On the pavement there was a confused scramble. Two policemen appeared. One was laid hors de combat by a kick on the knee-cap from Toller. The two men fled into the darkness, followed by a hue-and-cry. They tacked through alleys and raced down dark mews, and clambered over walls. Fortunately for them, the people they passed, who might have tripped them up or aided in the pursuit, merely fled indoors. The people in Wapping are not always on the side of the pursuer. But the police held on.. The siege of Aztec Street lasted three days and four nights. On forcing a panel of the front door, Sub-Inspector Wraithe, of the V Division, was shot through the chest. It was known that in the basement a considerable quantity of petrol had been stored. The contents had probably been carefully distributed over the most inflammable materials in the top rooms. The fire broke out, as one witness described it, "almost like an explosion." Orming must have perished in this. Francis Lowes-Parlby, K.C. was one of the darlings of the gods. His father had distinguished himself at the bar before him, and had amassed a modest fortune. "I have a perfectly clear recollection of Wych Street. Some of the people in the southern part of the country were called Spar-tans. The name of their land was La-co´ni-a, and so they were sometimes called La-cons. There was in the northern part of Greece a land called Mac´e-don; and this land was at one time ruled over by a war-like king named Philip.. The Spartans were afraid of the king of Sparta. King Philip bought a fine horse called Bu-ceph´a-lus. He was a noble an-i-mal, and the king paid a very high price for him. But he was wild and savage, and no man could mount him, or do anything at all with him.. Alexander ran up to Bu-ceph-a-lus, and turned his head toward the sun. He had noticed that the horse was afraid of his own shadow. He then spoke gently to the horse, and patted him with his hand. When he had qui-et-ed him a little, he made a quick spring, and leaped upon the horse's back.Everybody expected to see the boy killed outright. But he kept his place, and let the horse run as fast as he would.. Alexander reined in Bucephalus and rode back to the place where his father was standing. He leaped to the ground, and his father ran and kissed him. Alexander became the most famous king and warrior that was ever known; and for that reason he is always called Alexander the Great. The horse carried him through many countries and in many fierce battles, and more than once did he save his master's life. They were said to be always together, for when one of them was seen, the other was sure to be not far away. But the horse would never allow any one to mount him but his master.

Androclus hid himself in a wild wood for many days. He saw that the lion was not angry, but that he limped as though his foot hurt him. The lion stood quite still, and rubbed his head against the man's shoulder. He seemed to say,--"I know that you will help me.". Androclus was taken back to Rome by soldiers who found him in a cave. He and the lion became good friends and slept together at night. Androclus then decided to fight the lion for the first time. He took the thorn in his fingers and pulled the lion out.. Androclus was almost dead with fear, for the roars of the lion could already be heard. He looked up, and saw that there was no pity in the thousands of faces around him. Androclus gave a great cry, not of fear, but of gladness. It was his old friend, the lion of the cave.. Androclus was set free, and the lion was given to him for his own. A little boy called An-to-ni-o Ca-no´va lived with his grand-fa-ther. He was a puny lad, and not strong enough to work. But he liked to go with his grandfather to the stone-yard. While the old man was busy, he would play among the chips. Sometimes he would make a little statue of soft clay; sometimes he would take hammer and chisel, and try to cut a statue from a piece of rock.. The story of a young boy who became a stone-cutter is told in the novel "The Little Engine That Could" The boy, named Antonio, was born into a poor family but grew up to become a well-known and talented artist. The story of Antonio's life is told by his grandson, who is called "The Great" and is called a "sculp-tor" by his family. The boy's story is told through the eyes of Antonio, who tells it to his grandson's friends. The tale is said to have been inspired by the story of the Little Engine that Could, and the story is believed to be based on a true story.. The boy could not cook, and he was not old enough to wait on the table; but he could wash the pans and kettles, and as he was smart and quick, he could help in many other ways. Then there was a crash in the dining room, and a man rushed into the kitchen with some pieces of marble in his hands. He was pale, and trembling with fright. "I have broken the statue that was to stand at the center of the table. I cannot make the table look pretty without the statue. What will the Count say?". Antonio Ca-no-va left his pans and kettles, and went up to the man who had caused the trouble. "If you had another statue, could you arrange the table?" he asked. "Cer-tain-ly," said the man; "that is, if the statue were of the right length and height." "Will you let me try to make one?" asked Anto-nio. "Perhaps I can make something that will do," he said.. Two hundred pounds the lump weighed, and it had just come in, fresh and clean, from the dairy on the mountain. With a kitchen knife in his hand, Antonio began to cut and carve this butter. In a few minutes he had molded it into the shape of a crouching lion; and all the servants crowded around to see it. "How beautiful!" they cried. "It is a great deal pret-ti-er than the statue that was broken.". "Truly, my friends," he said, "this is as much of a surprise to me as to you." And then he called to his head servant, and asked him where he had found so wonderful a statue. "It was carved only an hour ago by a little boy in the kitchen," said the servant. "My name is Antonio Canova," said he, "and I have had no teacher but my grandfather the stonecutter" "How odd that he should choose to make it of butter!" asked the Count's friends. "None but a very great artist could ever carve such a figure," they said. "And how odd that they should have chosen butter!" they added.. The best artists in the land were impressed with his work. They invited him to a dinner. He became known as one of the greatest sculptors in the world. He died in 1875. His work is still admired today. He is buried in the town of Canova, near the town where he was born, in the village of Canva, Italy. His wife, Maria, died in 1896.

Others tried clubs and stones, but with no better luck. The lines were still un-bro-ken. What could the poor country people do against such foes as these? They came from the mountains and valleys to try what they could do to save their land. They knew they had to break their lines. They had to fight to the end.. The Swiss army was in danger of being defeated. A man stepped out and said he would break the lines. He had nothing in his hands, neither club nor stone nor other weapon. He ran forward. "Follow me!" he cried to his friends. "Switzerland shall be free" The Swiss army won the battle. The war ended in 1815. The Swiss people were never again at war. Arnold's friends rushed bravely after him. They fought with whatever they had in hand. They snatched spears and shields from their foes. They only thought of their homes and their dear native land. The Swiss army won the battle, and the war ended in victory.

Diogenes the Great lived in Greece. He slept in a tub or barrel, and said wise things to those around him. The man said: 'I am a man of wisdom, and I will help you.' He then told him to go and find a man, and the man followed him with a lantern. He said: "I am seeking an honest person to help me with my burden. Alexander went to see Diogenes, but the wise man did not come. He found him lying on the ground by his tub, en-joying the heat and the light of the sun. Alexander asked him to stand on one side, so as not to keep the sunshine from him. "Yes," he said, "You can stand a little on one-side, so that you can keep the sun from me." Alexander was much sur-prised, but it did not make him angry; it only made him admire the strange man all-the-more. He said: "I have heard a great deal about your wisdom. Is there anything I can do for you?". "Say what you will; if I were not Alexander, I would like to be Diogenes

Oliver Gold-smith wrote many de-light-ful books, some of which you will read when you are older. He was always ready to help others and to share with them anything that he had. He gave away so much to the poor that he was always poor himself. One day a poor woman asked him to go and see her husband, who was sick and could not eat. He found that the man had not had work for a long time and was not sick, but in distress; and, as for eating, there was no food in the house. The woman called Goldsmith and he gave her some med-i-cine for her husband.. Goldsmith gave her a little paper box that was very heavy. Goldsmith had given them all the ready money that he had. On the top were the di-rec-tions: "TO BE TAKEN AS OFTEN AS NE-CES-SI-TY REQUIRES" The woman took the box home and opened it. It was full of pieces of money. The money was all ready to be taken.

George Washington was given a hatchet by his father when he was a boy. He used it to chop down a small cherry tree. When his father came home, he was very angry about the tree's death. He said that it was the only tree of its kind in the country. He also said that the tree had cost him a great deal of money. George Washington said that he would have killed the tree himself if he had known who had cut it down, and that he was proud of his hatchet for doing so. The story of George Washington is told in the novel "The Peculier" by George Washington, who was born in 1777. The novel is about the life of GeorgeWashington.. Grace Darling was the daughter of the light-house keeper, and she had lived by the sea as long as she could re-mem-ber. In the darkness of the night, above the noise of the winds and waves, she heard screams and wild cries. When day-light came, she could see the wreck, a mile away, with the angry waters all around it. She could not save the poor, half-drowned men who were there.. Grace's father and she rowed toward the wreck. The fierce waves broke against the boat, and it would have been dashed in pieces. After many trials, Grace's father climbed upon the wreck, while Grace herself held the boat. She could see the men clinging to the masts. "Let us go out in the boat at once!" she cried. "We must at least try to save them." Her father could not say, "No". Grace Darling was no less tender as a nurse than she had been brave as a sailor. She cared most kindly for the ship-wrecked men until the storm had died away and they were strong enough to go to their own homes. She lies buried now in a little church-yard by the sea, not far from her old home. A mon-u-ment has been placed in honor of the brave girl. It is a figure carved in stone of a woman lying at rest, with a boat's oar held fast in her right hand.

The Romans did not have very many fighting men at that time, and they knew that they were not strong enough to meet the Etruscans in open battle. So they kept themselves inside of their walls, and set guards to watch the roads. One morning the army of Por-se-na was seen coming over the hills from the north. They were marching straight toward the wooden bridge which spanned the river at Rome. Among the guards at the bridge, there was a brave man named Ho-ra´ti-us. He saved the day by crossing the river and saving the city of Rome from the E-trus-cans.. Horatius was on the farther side of the river, and when he saw that the Etruscans were so near, he called out to the Romans who were behind him. "Hew down the bridge with all the speed that you can!" he cried. "I, with the two men who stand by me, will keep the foe at bay" But just then Porsena's horsemen dashed toward them again. "Run for your lives!" said Horatius to his friends, "I will keepThe road." They turned, and ran back across the bridge.. Horatius was the best swimmer in Rome. He leaped into the deep, swift stream. Shout after shout greeted him as he climbed upon the bank. He was half-way across the river, and safe from the spears and darts which Porsena's soldiers hurled after him. He still had his heavy armor on. When he sank out of sight, no one thought that he would ever be seen again. But he was a strong man, and a good swimmer. The next minute he rose. He saw the white porch of his own home among the trees on the other side of the stream; and then he turned quickly around and ran back to Rome. His friends stood ready to help him. The bridge toppled over to one side, and then fell into the water.. Horatius kept Porsena out of Rome, but he had done a deed which they could not help but praise. The Romans called him Horatius Co´cles, which meant the "one-eyed Hor atius," because he had lost an eye in defending the bridge. They gave him as much land as he could plow around in a day. And for hundreds of years afterwards--

Napoleon wanted to take his soldiers into It-a-ly. Between France and Italy there are high mountains called the Alps. The tops of the mountains are covered with snow. Napoleon waited only to see that everything was in good order. Then he gave the order to march. The long line of soldiers and horses and cannon stretched for twenty miles. It was a long way from France to Italy, but it was the only way. It took 60,000 men to cross the Alps where there was no road. They crossed the Alps in a single day.. "The man who has made up his mind to win," said Napoleon, "will never say 'Im-pos-si-ble'" "Charge!" was the cry of the French army. "Every man did his best, and the

Julius Ceasar was the greatest of all the Romans. He was a brave warrior, and had conquered many countries for Rome. He knew how to make men both love and fear him. He made himself the ruler of Rome.. Ceasar was crossing a narrow sea in a boat. Before he was halfway to the farther shore, a storm overtook him. He had crossed the sea many times, but never in such a storm as this.

King Alfred was driven from his kingdom by the Danes. He was hiding on an is-land in a river. A beggar came to his door asking for food. The king gave him half of a loaf and a little wine. The beggar thanked the king for his kindness, and went on his way. The men who had gone out to fish came back the next day. They found the king and queen still hidden on the is- land. They had not been seen for a long time.. The king was glad, and he and his people were more hopeful than they had ever been before. They had three boats full of fish, and they said, "We have caught more fish to-day than in all the other days that we have been on this island" The king lay awake for a long time, and thought about the things that had happened that day. At last he fancied that he saw a great light like the sun, and in the midst of the light there stood an old man with black hair, holding an open book in his hand. The king looked and wondered, but was not afraid.. The man said, "Go forth bravely, and within seven days your en-e-mies shall be beaten, and you shall go back to your kingdom to reign in peace" Then the light went out, and the man was seen no more. King Alfred ruled wisely and well over all his people for the rest of his days, and ruled wisely over them for the remainder of his life. The Danes were filled with fear, but the king blew his horn three times very loudly, and his friends heard it, and they cheered loudly. They said they would follow him and fight for him so long as they had

Alfred the Great was a king of Eng-land. He was killed by the Danes, who had come from over the sea to fight the English. The king fled alone, in great haste, through the woods and swamps. He is remembered as one of the greatest monarchs of all time.. King Alfred was very tired and hungry. He begged the wood-cut-ter's wife to give him something to eat and a place to sleep in her hut. She had no thought that he was the king. She said, "I will give you some supper if you will watch these cakes. I want to go out and milk the cow;. "You lazy fellow!" she cried. "See what you have done!" "You want some-thing to eat, but you do not want to work!" "I have been told that she even struck the king with a stick," he says.

King Canute was a Dane; but the Danes were not so fierce and cruel then as they had been when they were at war with King Alfred. The great men and of-fi-cers who were around King Canute were always praising him. The king was a man of sense, and he grew very tired of hearing such foolish. Canute sat down on the beach and asked the sea to obey him. The sea came in, just as it always did. Canute said, "I command you to come no farther! Waves, stop your rolling, and do not dare to touch my feet!" But the tide came in.. Canute threw off his crown, and threw it down upon the sand. It came up around the king's chair, and wet not only his feet, but also his robe. His officers stood about him, alarmed, and won-der

King John of England was harsh and cruel to his people. He made up his mind to put a stop to the way an abbot lived. King John sent for the old man to come and see him. "I hear that you keep a far better house than I do," he said.. "O king!" said the abbot, "I beg to say that I am spending nothing but what is my own" "How dare you do such a thing? Don't you know that no man in the land ought to live better than the king?" ". "I will try to answer them, O king!" said the abbot. "Your fault is plain, and unless you can answer me three questions, your head shall be cut off, and all your riches shall be mine.". The abbot went to a great school, called a u-ni-ver´si-ty, to see if any of the wise pro-fess-ors could help him. But they shook their heads, and said that there was nothing about King John in any of their. "You help me!" cried the abbot. "Have you never yet heard that a fool may teach a wise man wit? I think I can help you out of your trouble" "If nothing else can be done, I can at least die in your place," said the shepherd.. The king did not know the shepherd. He asked him three questions. The shepherd replied: "How long shall I live?" The king laughed. Then he mounted his horse, and with a great train of servants set out for London.. "You must rise with the sun," said the shepherd, "and you must ride with the Sun until it rises again the next morning" "Indeed," he said, "I did not think that it. "A merry fellow you are," said the king, "and you shall be the Abbot of Canterbury in your master's place" "O king! that cannot be," said he, "for I can neither read nor write

King Max-i-mil´ian of Ba-va´ri-a was walking in the country. The sun shone hot, and he stopped under a tree to rest. The king lay down on the soft grass, and looked up at the white clouds sailing across the sky. Then he took a little book from his pocket.. The king saw a little bare-foot-ed boy in the open field near the road. He was tending a large flock of geese that were picking the short grass, and wading in a shallow brook. He held a gold piece in his hand and asked the boy, "How would you like. "I am silly enough to believe that you will give me that gold piece for running a mile, and fetch-ing you a book," said the boy. "Who says that you are silly?" said the king. "But if I give it to you now, perhaps you will believe me," he said.. Maximilian gave the king lessons in whip cracking. The geese missed their master at once. With a great cac-kling and hissing they went, half flying, half running. The king ran after them, but he could not run fast. He tried to crack the whip, but it was of no use.. Maximilian, the king of Germany, lost his goose-herd. The goose boy returned with the book. Maximilian scolded the goose boy for leaving the geese with him. The geese were soon far away, and had entered a garden.. The boy took the gold, and thanked the giver. He looked up into the king's face and said, "You are a very kind man,

The story of Mignon is told by a young man named Wil-helm. He met a little girl coming down the stairs of an inn. He caught her in his arms and asked her to whom she belonged. She gave him a sharp, dark look, slipped out of. Wilhelm saw a great outcry among the crowd that was watching the rope-dan-cers. He saw that the master of the dancers was beating little Mignon with a stick. He ran and held the man by the collar. "If you touch her again, one of us shall never leave this spot".  Wilhelm could not find Mignon, and it was not until the ropedancers had left the town that she came to him. "You are to live with me now, and you must be a good child," he said. "I will try," she said. From that time she tried to do all that she could for Wilhelm and his friends.. Mignon was waiting for Wilhelm when he came home. She asked him if she might dance. He told her that she might. She arranged the eggs in the form of certain figures. She skipped so fast among the eggs, she trod so closely beside them, that you would have thought she must crush them all.. Wilhelm forgot all his cares. He watched every motion of the child. He almost forgot who and where he was. He praised her, petted her, and hoped that she had not tired herself too much. She sang to him. The song which he liked best was one whose words he had never heard before..  Wilhelm asked her to speak the words over and over again. The men of Gotham hated the king, for they knew that he was a cruel, bad man. What should they do? They chop down the big trees in the woods, so that they will block up all the roads that lead into the town. The king's horse-men would have a hard time of it. The king came, and saw that the road had been blocked up. He asked two country lads that were passing by. They said it was the men of Gotham. The king said he would send his sher-iff into their town, and have their noses cut off.. Dobbin, the wisest of them all, said, "Let me tell you something. Many a man has been punished because he was wise, but I have never heard of any one being harmed because he is a fool" "But what shall we. The sheriff stopped his horses, and asked what they were doing. The old men were rolling big stones up the hill, and all the young men were looking on, and grunting very loudly. ". A man rode past a field where men were building a stone wall. He asked them why they were doing it, and they said there was a cuck-oo in. The sheriff next met a man who was carrying a door on his back. He asked the man why he didn't leave the door at home too. The man replied that he was afraid of thieves.. The sheriff rode on with his men; but every one that they met was doing some silly thing. The king laughed, and said that if that was the case, he would not harm them, but would let them keep

A seed of some kind had fallen between the stones. It had sprouted; and now a tiny green leaf was pushing its way up out of the ground. The time dragged slowly by. There was no work to be done, no one to talk with. The only pastime was walking back and forth in the paved prison yard. One fine morning in spring, Char-ney was taking his walk in the yard. He was counting the. The plant was much stronger and greener than it was the day before. Charney was about to crush it with his foot, when he saw that there was a kind of soft coating over the leaf. "Ah!" said he. "This coating is to keep it safe. I must not harm it.". "O my Pic-cio-la!" he cried. "It would have been dead long ago, if I had not seen that you thought so much of it" "Picciola must have a house," he said.. "A man built a little house around a plant in a garden" "He felt that he must write down the doings of his little pet" "I will see if I can make one" "The summer passed by, Picciola grew more lovely every day" "But one sad morning it began to droop". The stones of the prison yard would not let the plant live. Charney did not know what to do. He gave it water, but still it drooped. He would ask the great Napoleon, the em-per-or himself, to save his plant. But this was a thing which the jailer dared not do.. Charney gave the plant to a young girl, who promised to carry it to Napoleon. The em-per-or's kind wife had heard the story of Charney's care for the plant. She saw the handkerchief on which he had written of its pretty ways. "Surely," she said, "it can do us no good to

John Smith came to this country many years ago, when there were great woods everywhere, and many wild beasts and Indians. One day when Smith was in the woods, some Indians came upon him, and made him their pris-on-er. They led him to their king, and in a short time they made ready to put him to death. But just then a little Indian girl rushed in. She ran and threw herself between Smith and the up-lift-ed clubs. She clasped Smith's head with her arms. The king and all his great men stood around to see. The Indians raised their clubs. In another moment they would fall on Smith'sHead. But the girl, Po-ca-hon´tas, ran and ran and fought to save him. She was the daugh-ter of the king. The story is told in the book, "The Story. "O father!" she cried, "spare this man's life. I am sure he has done you no harm, and we ought to be his friends" The men with the clubs could not strike, for they did not want to hurt the child. The king at first did not know what to do. Then he spoke to some of his war-riors, and they lifted Smith from the ground. They untied the cords from his wrists and feet, and set him free. The next day the king sent Smith home; and several Indians went with him to protect him from harm.

Sir Humphrey Gilbert was one of the first men who tried to make a set-tle-ment in A-mer-i-ca. Twice did he bring men and ships over the sea, and twice did he fail, and sail back for England. The men on the "Hind" saw Sir Humphrey sitting on the deck of the "Squirrel" with an open book in his hand.. "Be brave, my friends! We are as near heaven on the sea as on the land" -- Sir Humphrey. A soldier was wounded in a battle and was dying of thirst. A friend brought him some water from a brook. The soldier drank the water, and was revived. The man was no better off than the poorest man in the field, he thought. He was a no-ble-man, whom everybody loved for his gen-tle-ness and kindness. He thought: "Here, Sir Philip," he said, "I have brought you some clear, cool water from the brook." The soldier was a soldier called Philip. He had been wounded, and would die; and he was suf-fer-ing much with pain and thirst.. The name of Sir Philip Sidney will never be for-got-ten. He was the name of a Chris-tian gen-tle-man who always had the good of others in his mind. Rich and poor, high and low, all felt that they had lost a friend. All mourned the death of the kindest, gentlest man they had ever known. The wist-ful look in the poor man's face spoke plainer than words. He said, "Here, my comrade, take this. Thy need is greater than mine."

The story of Sir Walter Raleigh is told in the novel "The Adventurer" The story of Raleigh's life is told through the eyes of a young boy. The story is told from the point of view of a boy who has just learned to walk. The boy learns to walk on his hands and knees. He also learns to use his feet to avoid stepping in the mud. The tale is told by the boy's father, who was also called Walter Raleigh. The book is called "The Adventures of Walter Raleigh" and is published by Simon & Schuster at £16.99. For more information, visit www.simonandschulder.com. For confidential support call the Samaritans on 08457 90 90 90, visit a local Samar. The Queen of England was coming down the street. She saw the dirty puddle in the street, and the handsome young man with the scar-let cloak, stand-ing by the side of it. How was she to get across? Young Raleigh, when he saw who was coming, forgot about himself. There was only one thing that he could do, and no other man would have thought of that. He took off his scarlet cloak and spread it across the puddle. The queen could step on it now, as on a beautiful carpet. She was safely over the ugly puddle, and her feet had not touched. The queen made him a knight. From that time he was known as Sir Walter Raleigh, the queen's favorite. Raleigh and Sir Humphrey Gilbert were half-broth-ers. Sir Walter was with Sir Humphreys when he made his first voy-age to America, and was with him on his return. He was also with him when he went on his first voyage to America. He died in 1788. He is buried in the Tower of London, in the garden of St. James' Palace. He has a son, Raleigh Raleigh, and a daughter, Elizabeth Raleigh.. Sir Walter had seen the Indians smoking the leaves of the to-bac-co plant. He thought that he would do the same, and he carried some of the leaves to England. He proved that they would grow in the Old World as well as in the New. If you should ever go to Ireland, you may be shown the place where Sir Walter planted the few po-ta-toes which he carried over from America. He told his friends how the Indians used them for food. He tried sev-er-al times to send men to this country to make a set-tle-ment. But those whom he sent found only great forests, and wild beasts, and sav-age In-di-ans. Some of them went back to England; some of them died for want of food; and. Englishmen had never used tobacco before that time. All who saw Sir Walter puff-ing away at a roll of leaves thought that it was a strange sight. The man saw the smoke curling over his master's head, and he thought that he was on fire. He ran out for some water. He found a pail that was quite full. He hurried back, and threw the water into Sir Walter's face. Of course the fire was all put out. And now tobacco is used in all countries of the world. It would have been well if Sir Walter Raleigh had let it alone
A Greek man built a house so small that his neighbors wondered how he could be content with it. He said: "I shall think myself happy if I can fill even it with true friends"

There was once a rich old man who was called the Bar-me-cide. He lived in a beautiful palace in the midst of flowery gardens. In the same land there was a poor man whose name was Schac-a-bac. His clothing was rags, and his food was the scraps which other people had thrown away. But he had a light heart, and was as happy as a king.. Schacabac told the Barmecide that he had not eaten for two days. "You must be almost dead with hunger; and here I have plenty and to spare!" said the Barmside. "Come and wash with me," he said. "Ho, boy! Bring in the water to wash our hands, and then order the cook to hurry the supper". Schacabac thought that he un-der-stood the joke, and he made pretense of taking food, and passing it to his mouth. Then he began to chew, and said, "You see, sir, I lose no time" The Barmecide said, "Come now, let us have supper". Schacabac was almost dead with hunger, but he was too polite not to do as he was bidden. The Barmecide spoke of sweet-meats and fruits; and Schacabic made believe that he was eating them.. "I will drink no wine, for it is for-bid-den," said Schacabac. The Barmecide seized him by the hand. "I have long wished to find a man like you," he said. "Come and live with me, and manage my house" And so SchacAbac lived with the Barmcide many years, and never again knew what

A-tri is the name of a little town in It-a-ly. It is a very old town, and is built half-way up the side of a steep hill. A long rope that reached almost to the ground was fas-tened to the bell. The smallest child could ring the bell by pulling upon this rope.. The king said that the bell must never be rung except in case of need. Many years passed by after this. Many wrongs were righted, many ill-doers were punished. At last the hempen rope was almost worn out. The lower part of it was un-twist-ed; some of the strands were broken. It became so. The judges of Atri were worried that a child could be wronged and not know about it. They ordered a rope to be put on the bell, but could not find one in all Atri. A man ran into his garden and returned with a long grape-vine, which he fastened to the bell. The rope hung down to the ground.. A man who had once been a brave knight became a miser. He sold all that he had, except his horse, and went to live in a little hut on the hill-side. Day after day he sat among his money bags, and planned how he might get more gold. He left his horse in his bare stall, half-starved, and shiv-er-ing with cold.. "I will turn him out to shift for himself, and pick grass by the roadside. If he starves to death, so much the better" "The boys threw stones at him, the dogs barked at him. In all the world there was no one to pity him" "He stretched his thin neck, and took one of the tempting morsels in his mouth". The judges heard it. They wondered who it could be who would ring the bell at such a time. When they passed through the gate, they saw the old horse nibbling at the vine. "Ha!" cried one, "it is the miser's steed. He has. The horse had been left to die on the hills while his master counted his gold. The judges ordered that half of the gold be set aside for the horse's care. The horse was given a new stall and a dinner such as he had not had in many a day.

In Scotland, in the time of King Robert Bruce, there lived a brave man whose name was Doug-las. His hair and beard were black and long, and his face was tanned and dark. He was a good friend of the king, and one of his strongest helpers. The English people became very much afraid of him. Nothing could frighten an English lad more than to tell him that the Black Douglas was not far away.. The Black Douglas and his men were creeping on hands and feet toward the foot of the castle wall. Some of them were dragging ladders behind them through the grass. But they had left watch-men on the wall to see that the Scottish soldiers did not come upon them un-a-wares; and so they felt quite safe. But the dark objects were not cattle.. The woman watched them until the last one had passed around a corner out of sight. She was not afraid, for in the dark-en-ing twi-light they looked indeed like cattle. They would soon be climbing to the top of the wall. None of the English soldiers dreamed that they were within many miles of the place. Many of them were killed, and in a little while the Black Douglas and his men were the masters of. The mother and her children went back to

blind men stood by the road-side every day, and begged from the people who passed. When they were told that the great beast was before them, they asked the driver to let him stop so that they might see him. They thought that by touching him they could learn just what kind of animal he was. The first one happened to put his hand on the elephant's side. "Well, well!" he said, "now I know all about this beast. He is exactly like a wall." The second felt only of the elephant’s tusk. "My brother," he said,. "You are mistaken. He's not at all like a Wall." The third happened to take hold of the trunk. "Both of you are wrong," he says. "He is more like a spear than anything else". The six blind men sat by the roadside all day, and quarreled about the elephant. The sixth was very blind indeed, and it was some time before he could find the elephant at all. At last he seized the animal's tail. "O foolish fellows!" he cried. "You surely have lost your senses. This elephant is not like a wall, or a spear, or snake, or tree; neither is he like a fan. But any man with a par-ti-cle of sense can see that he is exactly like a rope." Then the elephant moved on, and the six men quarrelled about him for some time. The elephant then moved on and the men sat on the roadside, still quarreling about him, until he had gone. The story of the elephant is told in the novel "The Elephant and the Seven Men". A mighty army, led by the great King of Persia, was marching along the seashore. The men armed themselves, and made haste to drive back their foe. The women staid at home, weeping and waiting, and with fear. There were so many of them that no man could count them. They were called the Persian soldiers. They came from the east. They had come to take over Greece. They would take over all Greece. And they would do it in a few days. They said: "No: we will be free." And so they did. They took over. And so did all of Greece. But they did not take over the whole country.. Le-on-i-das and his Spartans held their ground. The Persians came forward, only to meet death at the points of their spears. At last their spears were broken; yet still they stood side by side, fighting to the last. Some fought with swords, some with daggers, and some with only their fists and teeth. When the sun went down, there was not one Spartan left alive. Where they had stood there was only a heap of the slain, all bristled over with spears and arrows. The Persian army of the Persians was kept at bay. But when the sun goes down,there is not one Spartans left alive, only a pile of slain, bristled with spears.. A great king in the Far East was always sad when a story was ended. He sent word into every city and town and country place, offering a prize to any one who should tell him an endless tale. He said, "To the man that will tell me a story which shall last forever, I will give my fairest daugh-ter for his wife". The king's daughter was very pretty, and there were many young men in that country who were willing to do anything to win her. But none of them wanted to lose their heads, and so only a few tried for the prize. "If any man shall try to tell such a story and then fail, he shall have his head cut off," said the king.. The story-teller began his tale. "I have a pleasant story about locusts which I would like to relate," he said. "But if he fails, he shall lose his head," said the king. The story went on for days and weeks, and the man kept on saying, "Then another locust went in and carried away a grain of corn". The story-teller married the king's daughter and lived happily in the land for many years. But his father-in-law, the king, did not care to listen to any more stories. In the North Sea there is a great rock called the Inch-cape Rock. It is twelve miles from any land, and is covered most of the time with water.
